Excited to announce our seed investment in @qdayclock

Imagine waking up in a decade to find your Bitcoin wallet drained. Not because of a hack, but because the math that once protected it has silently broken down. No alerts. No patch. Just physics, catching up.

The financial world  both traditional and decentralized  runs on cryptography. But that foundation is under threat from quantum computing.

In 2024, Google_ Willow chip solved in minutes a problem that would take the best classical supercomputer longer than the age of the universe to crack. Experts estimate that quantum computers will reach the threshold to break today_ cryptographic systems sometime between 2035 and 2050. Close enough to matter now.

The U.S. government is pushing federal agencies and the banks they work with to migrate to post-quantum standards by 2030. But for decentralized financial systems, coordination is much harder. There_ no single vendor or update cycle. The upgrade path is messy.

Most of crypto is sleepwalking toward this risk, even though the stakes are existential. But one team is sounding the alarm and building the safety net.

That_ why we led an investment in Project Eleven @qdayclock.

Project Eleven is building the infrastructure crypto needs to survive and thrive in a post-quantum world.

Their first product, yellowpages, is like a fire escape for your Bitcoin. It lets holders generate quantum-resistant keys, prove ownership of their existing addresses, and publicly register those proofs, without moving funds or waiting for a protocol upgrade. It_ simple, free, and available today. It_ a way to secure what you already own against a threat that hasn_ arrived, yet.

Project Eleven is led by @apruden08, someone I_e known and respected for years. We first met at Andreessen Horowitz, where we were both investment partners on the crypto team. Even then, it was clear that, as a former Special Forces officer, he had a rare combination of vision, rigor, and operational grit. He later joined Aleo (a Variant portfolio company) as COO, where he led the team at the frontier of decentralized systems and bleeding-edge cryptography. This isn't  theory for him. It_ mission-critical work  and he_ built his career preparing for exactly this moment.

We_e proud to partner with Alex and the Project Eleven team as they help crypto meet its next great challenge. Quantum won_ arrive with a bang. But when it does come, it will be too late to scramble. The time to harden our systems is now, and Project Eleven is leading the way.

Love seeing two Variant-backed teams come together with a shared goal:

Big congrats to the @dawn_wallet  and @tfh_technology @worldcoin teams.

Try yellowpages here: yellowpages.xyz/
It_ free, open-source, and helps Bitcoin holders prepare for a post-quantum world_ithout moving funds.

Likely wrong dichotomy: 

Yield-generating stablecoins vs.  Payment stablecoins.

There will be an infinite number of bespoke, branded stablecoins held at rest for yield generation, but only a few major ones used for inter-stable settlement due to liquidity network effects.

Yield-generating stablecoins are held for earning interest or rewards programs, while payment stablecoins are used for settlement.

Incomplete distinction:

For institutions, stables are primarily a messaging protocol innovation, like ACH or SWIFT, but where the 'medium is the message' (the message is both the state change and the trusted, instant settlement -- this the key innovation of blockchains) vs. legacy systems where the message and settlement are independent processes.

For consumers, stables are primarily an innovation in convenience and economics/incentives. They combine the potential for rewards and better economics with the convenience of instant global financial access (still being built out)

Tokens go in and out of vogue every market cycle. 

In a bear, tokens are seen as a category error. 
In a bull, tokens are popular again, usually with a new flavor.

I see some progress in the fact that outside of L1s and the  non-BTC boomer-coin complex, this cycle's most in-vogue tokens are associated with products people use. 

Because people use the products and love them, they  have cash flow, and token-holders are seeing the benefit of that.

I don't think its a coincidence that many of these tokens are built, and in some cases operated by unabashedly centralized core teams, or otherwise very lightly decentralized ones.

Its because its really hard to build a product people want, and near impossible to do it by committee. 

In crypto the phenomena of 'product tokens' started with exchange tokens and is still in early innings of getting iterated on. They likely won't get to final form this cycle, and while they're definitely not without problems, more of their economic activity is happening transparently onchain and thats a step in the right direction. 

So as a directional thought experiment, I find it useful to assume these types of tokens may stick around, because the market values them. Through that lens, is I find it useful to view the popularity of product-tokens as the product and beneficiary of two secular trends:

secular trend #1:
the democratization of investing: 

more and more people want to invest_ot just in crypto, but in stocks, levered ETFs, 0day options, prediction markets, treasury vehicles, perps, etc. 

this is because capital markets are where the average person can access asymmetric economic upside while economic growth is increasingly concentrated in smaller and smaller technology companies. 

people especially want to invest in products and services they love or have communities they love because they want to win-and-help-win. 

secular trend #2:
'live player' founder worship 

investors, especially retail, want to get behind people and ideas who are engaging, and who put numbers on the board. 

this trend really started in Silicon Valley, where founders of in-demand startups, like Zuck, were able to attract investment while retaining corporate control. 

where there's higher trust (e.g. high integrity founders, or more economic activity that is transparent onchain) investors can/could get comfortable with more limited rights. in these scenarios, ownership is more to do with economic alignment vs. more classical shareholder governance models.

so coming back to product tokens, i find it helpful to view them as instruments that principally offer that kind of economic alignment with product growth. users know the product, and they want to own a piece of it. 

yes there are policy implications to this train of thought, but setting that aside and looking purely at the commercial side of it, this is a new asset class that the market wants_nd if we assume markets can reason about risk, then mr. market should be able to price risk of more limited rights/protections. 

on the one hand, maybe these tokens should trade at a discount to equities because the risks are greater and protections lesser, but what we see in practice is the market assigning an ACCESS premium, because never before have retail investors had access to the kind of asymmetric early-stage economic alignment that product tokens offer. at scale, which will win out is a tougher question to answer.

on policy, i would say it simply needs to adapt to this new in-demand asset class, because its not going away. i think its positive that forthcoming rule-making allows the presence of a core team to play a continous role without necessarily making the asset a security, so long as tokenholders have ultimate transparency and control--e.g. cash flows onchain, open source, and can remove that team.

so in addition to decentralized infrastructure and core primitives, i think its directionally positive (though not without risk) the the market is leaning into a new flavor of tokens: product tokens with live players at the helm.

The most disruptive opportunities in crypto (so far) were invented because permissionless, decentralized networks uniquely made them possible. 

But disruptive areas in crypto like stablecoins and infra are shifting from invention to productization, and from ideology to pragmatism.

Historically, disruption is a pendulum that swings markets between open and closed solutions. Tempo is attempting to pick a point in that pendulum with the right mix of open/closed and maximum momentum. 

And my view is it ain't all bad if you care about impact.

From a year ago, on the next 10 yrs of smart contract blockchains:

> In meeting the market on its values, crypto is commercializing. Commercialization...takes good ideas to their largest possible audience, and thereby makes the most impact on the world. And commercialization often comes with compromises. The opportunity is to shape the nature of those compromises, and thereby, the outcome of that commercial impact. To do that, you have to drop ideological dogma, adapt to the game on the field, compete, and try to steer things in the direction you want them to go.

In 2021 I wrote about Product vs. Protocol in crypto, suggesting that protocols should "commoditize the complement" by giving away the products they build on top, in order to maximize growth and value of the underlying protocol (pocket playbook below)

This essay was inspired in part by what I observed @haydenzadams and the early Uniswap Labs team do at the outset: build a buttery smooth product to bootstrap liquidity in the Uniswap protocol.

Fast forward through years of regulatory purgatory that prohibited protocol monetization, and finally, in 2025, this strategy is coming back around. 

New chapter for tokens: own things you use, have that ownership be valuable; build networks bigger, faster because users are economically aligned with growth via the token.

Sundial has raised $23M to build the analytics platform for the AI era!

Our work is personal to me (though many have asked: Why? Aren't you into intuition and taste and experience which is ultimately unmeasurable?)

But hear me out: I love building, and I have a deep respect for it. Making something people love is one of the hardest and most humbling endeavors.

The art comes down to making high-quality decisions, which comes from an obsession with the cliff_ edge between customer understanding and product capability.

You need to know what_ working and what isn_.

That_ why data matters. Data is *information* about how reality works. At Sundial, we live by the mantra: diagnose with data; treat with design.

What does masterful decision-making look like? It comes down to 3 things:
1. extreme alignment
2. shared curiosity to unpeel deeper and deeper layers of truth
3. urgent execution

The very fact is that good intuition and taste comes from data internalized across many, many reps. 

Yes, reality is infinitely more complex than what can be measured. But measuring gives us a better grasp of reality.

Alas, using data well is like learning a new language. It requires years of skill and context building. It's easy to misuse, whether misguidedly or intentionally. I know this all too well.

Mastery requires everything from how to break down an ambiguous question, to fluently reading triangle charts and dense tables, to remembering the specific name of a specific column using a specific dialect of SQL.

Too many people, like me, regularly feel frustrated by 
a) how long it takes to get answers 
b) how to draw the right interpretations 
c) how much noise I have to wade through to find actually actionable insights.

Instead of greater confidence and quality, we get conflicting signals, cherry-picked facts, and analysis paralysis.

Sundial is our attempt to solve those problems.

We_e bottling up opinionated intelligence to guide decision-makers towards faster and more confident decisions. We envision a world where *everyone* can be their own expert analyst.

Sundial uses AI and expert analytical techniques to make insights accessible to every decision-maker. Exemplary analysis takes the listener through a story. Data should speak the language of business, not the other way around.

Sundial is also smart in the ways you_ expect of an AI-native tool. It_ not just about looking up data (_hat_ India ARR last month?), which has become table stakes; rather, Sundial can also tackle deep, complex analysis (_hy did ARR decline? What are my levers?).

In a crowded landscape of fragmented data tools_ashboards, notebooks, ETL systems_undial brings it all together into one intuitive platform.

wow, been a wild ride to mainnet.

some fun facts: uma and i started in 2021 working on zk bridging, until we realized the real problem wasn't bridging itself, it was that using zk was so horrendously complex that nobody could actually build with it.

we pivoted to making it possible to prove any piece of software.

i think we were one of the first teams to show that the risc-v zkvm approach was endgame. it's nice to see teams like zksync, scroll, and even ethereum now agree it's the right approach.

with this mainnet launch, we finally have the ingredients for easy-to-use, low-cost proving that teams need to scale zk in production. i'm also really excited to keep working with the talented hardware teams and provers who are tirelessly pushing to make zk 10-100x cheaper, which should onboard basically every crypto infra protocol to zk in the near future.

thank you to everyone who got us here: paradigm, the early adopters, and the oss developers who believed in the vision.

our work is only getting started.

Today, we are proud to announce Multicoin Capital liquid fund_ investment in ENA, the native token for Ethena Protocol, the issuer of USDe, the leading synthetic dollar.

Synthetic Dollars aim to generate yield and create stability by executing fully-collateralized delta-neutral trading strategies in financial markets. Ethena generates yield by monetizing the market_ demand for leverage via basis trade.

The most exciting thing about Ethena for us is that it sits at the intersection of three powerful trends reshaping modern finance: stablecoins, perpification, and tokenization.

1. Stablecoins

a) Ethena is the only synthetic dollar to have achieved meaningful distribution and liquidity outside of USDC and USDT. 

b) The true test of a synthetic dollar_ adoption is its acceptance as collateral on major exchanges. Ethena has succeeded in integrating USDe as a core form of collateral on major centralized exchanges like Binance and Bybit.

c) Another unique aspect of Ethena's strategy is its mild negative correlation with Fed Funds rates. As rates fall demand for leverage in crypto generally increases leading to higher funding rates. We have seen a version of this playout in 2021 when the spread between funding rates and treasury rates widened beyond 10%. (chart below)

d) Since inception, the protocol has generated close to $600 million in revenue  with over $450 million of that produced in just the past twelve months.

2. Perpification of Tokenized Equities & Fintechs distributing them to masses

a) Perps are a big market in crypto. In a roughly $4 trillion asset class that is crypto, perpetual contracts trade more than $100 billion per day with an open interest of more than $100B across CEX and DEX.

b) The global equity market is worth around $100 trillion  nearly 25 times larger than the entire crypto market. The US equity market alone is worth around $60 trillion.

c) Just like in crypto, there is strong demand for leverage among equity market participants. This is evident in the explosive growth of 0DTE (zero-day-to-expiry) options, which are mostly traded by retail investors and account for over 50% of SPX options volume.

d) Perpetuals are much easier for most investors to understand than options. We don_ expect perpetuals to replace the 0DTE options market, but they could capture significant market share.

e) As crypto regulations turn more favorable, fintechs around the world should increasingly embrace crypto. Today, most non-crypto-native users can only access a limited set of crypto assets, and only in spot form. We believe this group represents significant untapped demand for leverage.

f) We believe, as fintechs adopt crypto perpetuals, they will create a new distribution channel for these products, driving higher trading volumes and open interest, which in turn will expand the capacity and scalability of the basis trade that supports Ethena.

3. Tokenization

a) Today, access to hedge funds that have the infrastructure to do basis trades at scale is reserved for accredited investors and qualified institutional purchasers. Crypto is rebuilding the financial system from the ground up, making such opportunities accessible to everyone through tokenization.

b) In traditional finance, the closest parallel to tokenization is the ETF. Today, there are more ETFs than publicly listed single stocks in the U.S. ETFs package complex strategies into a single, tradable ticker that investors can easily buy, sell, or hold  without worrying about execution or rebalancing.

c) Ethena is starting by tokenizing the basis trade  but there_ nothing stopping Ethena from diversifying its yield sources over time.

Separately, the team has shown strong execution and risk management culture, and there is a line of sight to value capture for the ENA token.

Team, Risk Management and Value Capture

a) In our experience, Guy has proven to be one of the sharpest and most strategic thinkers in DeFi. The following quote stands out about his conviction in what he is building.

_ quit my job to build Ethena a few days after Luna collapsed and hired the team a couple of months post-FTX.  Guy Young, the founder of Ethena.

b) They have survived the largest hack, Bybit $1.4B and the largest deleveraging event, October 10 crash, in the same year, and did not lose a single dollar. That is a testament to their risk management ethos, which in my opinion are probably the most important factor in running basis trade.

c) There is a line of sight between now and fee switch activation and we believe that would be viewed favorably by the market.

Conclusion

To conclude, we believe that the opportunity for synthetic dollars is massive.

Ethena sits at the intersection of the three largest forces shaping the financial markets: stablecoins, perpification and tokenization, each of which is a source of compounding for Ethena.

They have demonstrated competence in risk management and there is a line of sight to value capture.

We are excited to be in for the ride.

how to spend crypto profits in ways that will actually make your life better:

- throw away every one of your socks and boxers. buy brand new, all the same color/style. your drawers will never look so good. 

- get a coach for whatever hobby you care about - sports, chess, art, language, it doesn't matter. just pay someone to shortcut your own learning time

- buy an in-home sauna if you have the space. it's  ~$3,000, the same as a high end TV, and if you use it everyday its absolutely worth it

- pay for a personal stylist to redo your wardrobe

- upgrade your zoom setup - nice camera, nice lights, nice microphone. this will boost your perceived credibility more than you think

- pay for your mom/dad/sibling to go on a fancy trip. pay for everything, including flights, hotels, food. it is the single thing that will make you feel like you made it, and the memory will last a lifetime.

- get an inroom IV drip when you travel and watch your jetlag disappear (s/o @calilyliu)

- pay for a 3 hour couple's massage. get the body scrub, it's better than you think.

- buy a package for facials and get one every ~6 weeks

- start getting haircuts every other week. nothing to make you feel fresh like a fresh cut. 

- only travel in nice cars. always get the expensive Uber/Grab/Careem. it will cost you ~$2k extra over the course of the year, but the feeling of luxury is worth much more (s/o @akshaybd)

- get a personal chef to come a few days a week and meal prep for you

- get an at-home massage every sunday

- if you're balding, get a red light hair mask. proven to work, and better to start sooner rather than later

- if you live near family/friends, pay a private chef to make a nice dinner for all of you once a month

- get a personal assistant for shopping, travel, and general research tasks. if you're in dubai or india, @dxbcare is quite good and affordable

- spend less time investing by giving your capital to professionals (liquid, venture, hedge funds, etc). make investing someone else's headache

- buy your wife/girlfriend/mother a new watch instead of buying one for yourself

- set aside a new wallet with a substantial amount of stables, yield farm on @jup_lend, and tell yourself that in 2 years you're going to give it to a family member

- buy a really nice mattress and desk chair and watch your back problems disappear

- send a gift (chocolates, cupcakes, etc) to your friends on their birthdays instead of just sending a text

The U.S. Should Lead on Stablecoins

Stablecoins are to finance what broadband was to the web: the substrate for something much larger. They represent one of the most tangible use cases for crypto_ digital dollar that moves at the speed of the internet, backed by real-world assets like U.S. dollars and Treasury bonds. What began as tools for crypto trading are now rapidly evolving into a foundational layer for global payments.

Stablecoins enable seamless global payment systems that truly meet the needs of a global economy. From major fintechs and traditional financial institutions to multinational enterprises, stablecoins are being used for remittances, merchant payouts, treasury management, and B2B flows, unlocking speed, interoperability, and transparency in ways legacy systems cannot.

They are quickly becoming core financial infrastructure. Citibank recently released a report projecting that stablecoin circulation could grow from approximately $230 billion today to $1.6 trillion (base case) or $3.7 trillion (bull case) by 2030. Citi also estimates that stablecoin issuers could drive more than $1 trillion in net new purchases of U.S. Treasuries by 2030_otentially surpassing any single foreign country as holders of U.S. government debt.

The financial implications of this shift are massive. New research from the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) found that stablecoin flows compress short-term Treasury bill yields, producing effects similar to small-scale quantitative easing, ultimately helping reduce the national debt at a time when it is otherwise soaring. There are also national security implications, given that the current largest holders of U.S. debt are foreign countries with complex geopolitical relationships.

Stablecoins are digital dollars, core payments infrastructure, and increasingly, monetary instruments with global policy relevance. As SEC Commissioner Mark Uyeda emphasized this week, tokenized assets offer _reater efficiencies in settlement, recordkeeping, and compliance. Regulatory frameworks should evolve to embrace these capabilities, not resist them.

Legislation like the GENIUS Act and the STABLE Act provides the regulatory scaffolding for stablecoin issuance in the U.S., including provisions for audits, 1:1 reserves, and state/federal oversight. This doesn_ just unlock safer onchain activity for existing crypto users; it creates an entirely new avenue for institutional use cases and helps preserve America_ economic leadership in the global financial system.

Tokenization won_ stop at money. The next wave will bring real-world assets (RWAs)_rom equities and bonds to funds and private credit_nchain. Stablecoins have demonstrated the playbook: start with simple, high-velocity use cases, build trust through scale, then extend the architecture to more complex assets.

We are rebuilding the financial system for a digital age from the ground up. This Administration, along with several federal courts, has acknowledged that reality. It_ time for leaders on both sides of the aisle in Congress to do the same.

This is a big milestone: half of the codebase, implementing MonadBFT, RaptorCast, blocksync, statesync, mempool, etc. is open source!

This codebase is a treasure trove of performant systems engineering work. We hope this materially pushes the space forward.

Step by step.
This is fun! It takes a special mind to know both the tech and the lore

What Monad has so far:

- High quality open-source C++/rust codebase with many HFT-style optimizations and architectural changes

- Public audits and clear docs that put the technology first. Transparency -- no hand-waving, no unsubstantiated claims

- High-performance system focused on true decentralization, running continuously in testnet with 186 globally distributed validators at 5000-10000 tps

- MonadBFT, a frontier consensus mechanism featuring 400ms block times, 800ms finality, large globally-distributed validator set, and tail-fork resistance

- Async Execution (while supporting EIP-7702 through the Reserve Balance mechanism)

- MonadDb for efficient merkle trie storage

- Native code compiler for frequently used contracts

- Interconnected community of smart, thoughtful crypto-natives who will grow in influence over the next few years

- Ecosystem of promising young startup founders, ready to take their shot

- Over $100m in ecosystem funding pre-mainnet

- Founder support through DeltaV, the Monad Founder Residency, Monad Madness, and more

- Monad Momentum, an incentives program focused on efficient UA and repeatable growth loops to help decentralized apps acquire normie users

- A north star of making open-source, decentralized systems more powerful

But there's still so much more to do. Are you excited?

The goal of the MON airdrop is to make people who eat, sleep, and breathe crypto the stakeholders in Monad, a new network built for true decentralization.

That includes both longtime Monad Community members as well as people who are new to Monad but active traders, collectors, or participants in crypto more generally.

It is still incredibly early in the story of Monad. If you are a longtime Monad Community member, you are a respected Unc here. Your influence and voice will have an outsized impact in shaping the culture of Monad and crypto more generally. Monad is growing, so please welcome the new folks as we prepare for the start of mainnet.

LOCKED MONAD TOKENS ARE NOT STAKEABLE

Monad has been built painstakingly over the past 3.5 years. We take a long term view and aren_ afraid to do things differently from others.

Today, ahead of the launch of the Public Mainnet, I_ like to share an important element of the Monad tokenomics design: locked MON may not be staked.

Time and time again in previous blockchain launches, the crypto community has had the same complaint: insiders ability to stake and earn rewards (liquid or otherwise) on locked tokens. We heard those complaints and are taking a firm stance on this matter, in an effort to set a new standard for the space.

The north star of Monad is true decentralization. The network will go live with 200 globally distributed validators that are run on consumer-grade hardware. While it would have been easier to cut corners, our team has taken the hard road in designing a system that delivers both performance and decentralization. What we build must stand the test of time. I believe that this firm stance on staking of locked tokens similarly positions Monad toward long-term success through better token distribution.

On a personal note, I appreciate the support of investors including @paradigm, @dragonfly_xyz, @ElectricCapital, and @CastleIslandVC. We build for the long term and are grateful for the long-term-oriented thinking and support of Monad_ earliest backers.

No shortcuts!

Today, we are announcing the MON public sale - an effort to give everyday people the opportunity to become a stakeholder in the Monad network token, days before the public network launch.

The public sale of MON will go live on Coinbase token sales, a new platform from Coinbase for token distribution, a week from today.

This is the very first public sale that Coinbase has hosted, and it will be made available to 80+ countries, including the United States of America.

7.5% of the total monad supply will be sold at a price of $0.025/token.

At the Monad Foundation, we think big. Over 285,000 accounts were made eligible for the MON airdrop, in an attempt to get people who eat, sleep, and breathe crypto to be the initial stakeholders of the Monad ecosystem. This public sale has the potential to extend the reach of Monad by extending the distribution of MON into the hands of millions of regular people.

This sale is attempting to fulfill crypto_ founding promise: open, fair, and inclusive finance.

Monad was built in part to onboard the general public to crypto, and provide them with the tech that is ready for mass adoption. The world is a big place, and crypto needs to grow far beyond the Crypto Twitter bubble.

Onwards! __

taking a break from my summer break to re-iterate that, yes, the avalanche app-chain architectural design is the correct one, especially as trillions of dollars worth of assets come online over the years. mono-chain design won't fit the bill

Avalanche is now in that mature growth cycle phase where there's no questions on product market fit. Avalanche is the web3 AWS.

Mission: digitizing all the world's assets by providing the world's premier app-chain infra. 

This is the absolute slowest Avalanche will ever be. 

This is the absolute least interoperable Avalanche will ever be. 

This is the absolute least feature-rich Avalanche will ever be. 

And the pace of improvement is actually *accelerating*. The power and sophistication of the codebase is just up-only here.

This week, I'm releasing a 70-minute conversation with
@el33th4xor - the Founder and CEO @avalabs - the company behind @avax

Emin dives deep into building decentralized systems, exposing Bitcoin_ flaws, and why Avalanche is engineered to scale when others stall.

From designing Karma in 2002 to taking on Ethereum maximalism, he_ been two steps ahead for two decades.

We talk about:

- Why centralized systems broke his trust - and his obsession with things that work
- The origins of Avalanche and how it's designed to scale with multi-chain architecture
- Why gaming giants like MapleStory and FIFA chose Avalanche
- Real-world assets, DeFi_ future, and rebuilding trustless financial rails
- The death of "dream-sellers" and the rise of "show me" builders

And much, much more!

Podcast out this week

Good points. Although everything in the gap analysis is subjective -- e.g. we have no federal law on algorithmic bias, but there's a good argument we don't need one because we have laws about discrimination generally.

Exceptional article by @KaiserKuo on how China's successful rise should force us to reconsider our assumptions about modernity. 

theideasletter.org/essay/the

It's frustrating how few American experts, outside some China specialists, will even entertain the quesiton of whether China represents a superior alternative to the Western development model for the next century.

I love my country and believe America has the edge, not because of some abstract "freedom" or democracy or cultural superiority, but because of our pluralism and openness to the world's most extraordinary talent. Yet those very attributes are now under siege in our country.

@KaiserKuo points to the universities as America's great advantage, which is part of it. So the great project of rethinking the post-WWII model of American higher education, occasioned by both political and technological factors, is also central to the geopolitical quesitons.

Next on my reading pile is @AngelaZhangHK's Convergence, arguing that the US policy response to China's economic and technological rise is making it more China-like: 

papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.

Intuitively, I think this is right, and consistent with Kuo's narrative.

I pointed out surprising similarities between the US and China in my article a few years back about China's Social Credit System. The connections have become stronger since then.

illinoislawreview.org/wp-con

The Trumpian right's willingness to to use state power aggressively to reorganize institutions, quash dissent, promote technological surveillance, and intervene in the economy is the other element that is making the two countries more similar.

I agree with Kuo's assessment that the challenge for Westerners is to take China seriously in order to develop a distinctive strategy that leverages our strengths for future prosperity, rather than rest on tired assumptions of the past.

Finally, I've found that actually talking to Chinese technologists and academics, both here and in China, is incredibly valuable, both for mutual understanding and devloping new ideas. There isn't enough of that informal communication happening today.

Lots of fake news about the EU_ Anti-Money Laundering Package flooded the timeline this weekend, so here_ a quick breakdown of what these new regulations actually mean.

First, the EU *is not* requiring an ID for every bitcoin transaction, as widely misreported. The EU_ AMLR only applies to so-called CASPs, or Crypto Asset Service Providers, which are defined custodians under the Markets in Crypto Assets Regulation (MiCAR) and was adopted 1.5 years ago.

This is bad, because it effectively requires most custodians to KYC their users, which is a major blow to small software firms trying to innovate.

Second, the AMLR requires CASPs to conduct due diligence on any funds that are sent to and from non-custodial wallets below 1000 EUR, and requires a proof-of-ownership of the non-custodial addresses when payments exceed 1000 EUR.

This also isn_ great because it effectively hinders the use of bitcoin as money, but it also isn_ KYC  due diligence is defined as a risk based approach which CASPs have some room to define, s.a. via the use of chain analysis firms. For transactions above 1000 EUR, most CASPs require something called the Satoshi Test, where you make a small tx to the CASP to prove that the address belongs to you.

Again, this isn_ news and was implemented in the beginning of this year via the Travel Rule.

Third, the EU bans cash transactions over 10k EUR for business transactions, but this too is already in effect in most countries, which have bans on cash tx as low as 1000 EUR, s.a. France or Spain.

What *is* new is that the AMLR bans CASPs from offering privacy coins  but some exchanges, s.a. Kraken EU, have already delisted coins like Monero as the EU considers them to be risk carrying assets.

I hope this helps clear up some of the misconceptions and remind you to read primary news sources yourself instead of relying on AI-fueled news aggregators feeding a frenzy for monetized clicks.

The AMLR is an absolute disaster and there_ no need to make it worse than it sounds, because things are already pretty bad in the EU for bitcoin.

When we first added onchain features at @Unchained_pod, it was an experiment.

Could a crypto media brand use crypto rails, not just talk about them?

Turns out, the answer is yes.

Today, we_e taking the next step:

Unchained is now live on Base, with our own mini-app inside the @baseapp (currently in beta).

�� Why we_e doing this:

1/8

I_e long said that I think media business models in the age of the internet are broken.

So I_e always been curious how crypto could provide solutions.

But it was only recently that crypto platforms started offering products and services that made sense for us.

2/8

Over the last year, we have been discussing how we could go deeper into crypto-native distribution:

 Value-for-value audio
 Onchain features
 And now, a home inside the Base App itself

3/8

It_ a step toward a real bet we_e making:

That the future of media won_ just be about crypto.
It will be built with it.

Base is helping us test what that can actually look like  in the real world, for real people.

4/8

Our new Base mini-app lets you:

 Watch livestreams of Unchained On Air
 Discover past episodes
 Access content without algorithms deciding for you

It_ simple. Just one login. And you're in.

5/8

We know this won_ be perfect.

But we_e been here long enough to know:

What the crypto industry does shapes the future.

6/8

So yes, we_l keep streaming on YouTube + X.

But now we_e also going live on Base.

Because being early means showing up to build, not just to watch.

And if even one piece of that helps push crypto media forward, it_l be worth it.

7/8

Watch Unchained On Air episodes directly onchain.

Just hit play inside the Base app:

 controlthestream.tv/unchaine

And if you_e been supporting Unchained all these years, thank you.

Advice to any human being of any age or gender:

Find out who YOU are, and do your best to live a life true to your most authentic self.

Don_ try to please others, don_ do what you think you *should* do.

Whether by meditating, walking, journaling, time in nature, etc., learn how to get in touch with what makes you happy and brings you joy. 

This world is full of opinions, people, and things that won't resonate with you. 

So learn how to find your inner voice, your intuition, your true feelings, what makes you come alive, and pursue whatever that is no matter what others think. 

This might sound simple but is harder than you think. The world now offers us so many inputs, it can make it hard to find what is most true inside us. So learning how to clear the clutter and get to that core is something you have to be committed to. 

But once you learn how to tune into that signal and follow it, your life will feel a lot more fulfilling.
And do you feel like you're less addicted to it?

Since the beginning of September, there has been almost an event per week that has celebrated, exhibited, honored work by artists from our community and a few more upcoming.

Carnegie
MoMA
Toldeo Museum of Art
Museum of Art + Light
Marfa
Art Basel Paris
Kunstsilo
Paris Photo
SFMOMA
Art Basel Miami
Node

There are also some incredible exhibitions happening at galleries like Heft and Offline in NYC that I didn_ even include in that list.

I_e been lucky enough to attend 3 so far and 3 more upcoming and yet I still have FOMO for missing the other half of them!

I_ impressed that almost all of these event are not NFT events, but highly-respected institutions or events, who are embracing people from our community more and more.

It_ also important to note that there is an incredible group of people who are working behind the scenes to make this all happen. Of the ones I personally know about, @NaughtalieStone working with Larva Labs and Mapan and many others, @bygrida curating an incredible group of Asian artists shown at Paris Photo, @miminguyenmimi bringing @yatreda to Paris Photo, @eli_schein with Art Basel Zero 10, and of course @redbeardnft who is the wizard behind the curtain making deals and connections happen. There are many many others to name, but those are the ones that I could recall off the top of my head.

In some ways, it does feel we have arrived, but yet this is only the beginning. I hope this will happen every year for decades to come with more and more artists being showcased at art institutions and events around the world.

Proof-of-Work provides unique expectations on genesis/origin, issuance, and inflationary/deflationary governance never seen before. It's transparent and true.

Was that too big a word sandwich for you?
If it was, then you better learn what the hell I just said becuz the next 12-24 months will get so stupid that most new investors won't know their head from their asses when they throw money at things called crypto.

Don't be that person and don't be that person who blindly leads others. Educate and protect yourself so you can educate others. There are good, honest projects out there and we owe it to ourselves and everyone else to learn how to discern between truth and bullshit.

Don't trust. Verify. 

If the projects vying for your attention and money aren't telling and showing you this by example, be wary.

This may be the most serious post I do but it's necessary with what is to come and has already been here. And most chains or projects won't say the quiet things out loud but I will. We need leaders, not leeches.

Thank you for listening to my ted talk. Carry on, beaches.

Litecoin represents a case study in durability. It has operated continuously for more than a decade, survived multiple market downturns, and consistently delivered on its value proposition: fast, low-cost, reliable transactions. In portfolio construction, Litecoin can be considered as:

_A diversification tool within a crypto allocation, offering exposure to a network distinct from Bitcoin but with a proven security model.
_A lower-beta play on transaction-focused cryptocurrencies, with relatively muted speculation compared to meme-driven assets like dogecoin.
_A long-term store of utility, benefiting from declining issuance and consistent adoption, even amid shifting market narratives.

For clients exploring digital assets, $LTC stands as one of the most tested and resilient networks in the space. Its combination of security, innovation, and practical utility underscores why it continues to endure as a key component of the crypto ecosystem.

Source: Josh Olszewicz, portfolio manager, Canary Capital (Pending Litecoin #ETF $LTCC)

On VISA's earnings call, the CEO, Ryan McInerney confirmed the pending support for Avalanche.

With the worst kept secret and news finally out that Circle & Stripe will be building their own L1 blockchains, I wanted to provide some thoughts on why our strategy has been focused on being the platform that enables L1 blockchain launches.

After the Robinhood announcement, CT did what it does - all the podcasters and naval gazers quickly re-pivoted back to _very institution will launch an L2 & _nsitutions chose Ethereum because Tom Lee. This was always nonsense because Robinhood considered many architectures, not all were L2s. The reality is and has been for a while that there will be millions of blockchains and there will be a mix of  L2s and L1s. It_ also true that many L2s will eventually graduate into becoming L1s.  If you are an institution with what may seem like unlimited resources, the thought of tying yourself and your infrastructure choice to the incumbents seems very risky! What if Ethereum, Arbitrum or Avalanche botches an upgrade and their business is interrupted? For many, this is a show stopper. Remember, there are still so many banks that use on-prem vs cloud

In addition, and I know people don_ want to hear this but, building an L1 does provide the ability to launch a token. The opportunity set of launching a token for an L1 that gets widely adopted is massive. Hyperliquid is a $42B FDV for one use case. How many other levers can a Stripe or Circle pull for that kind of marketcap? This is and has always been a key weakness for L2s and do not try and shill me your committee based nonsense. 

There is a reason Avalanche has built a network that allows for builders and enterprises to launch their own L1 blockchains, there is a market for it! That much is clear as well with FIFA, Maplestory & Gunzilla choosing to build on @avax. While Avalanche was not selected for these two (although it was at the top of the list for one of them), it validates the thesis that there will be many L1 blockchains and Avalanche can power that. It is not uncommon in the beginning of a new market for new entrants to want to build and own the whole stack, but history shows us that this is simply a detour, rather than a lasting trend. Seeing Stripe, Circle and Hyperliquid build their own L1 blockchains is great validation for the thesis that there will be millions of blockchains and Avalanche can power many of them.

Now add money.

The solution:

Yes, build markets around creators.
But don_ monetize the fans.

Fans give love, not liquidity.

The market should price attention, not affection.

ELON: ONLY INTERESTING SIMULATIONS SURVIVE

_f the simulation theory is true, then it is actually very likely that the most interesting outcome is the most likely. 

Because only the simulations that are interesting will continue. 

The simulators will stop any simulations that are boring because they're not interesting. 

In this reality that we live in, we run simulations all the time. 

When we try to figure out if the rocket's going to make it, we run thousands, sometimes millions of simulations just to figure out which path is the good path for the rocket and where can it go wrong? 

Where can it fail? 

But when we do these millions of simulations of what can happen with the rocket, we ignore the ones where everything goes right, because we have to address the situations where it goes wrong. 

And for AI simulations as well, like all these things, we keep the simulations going that are the most interesting to us. 

So, if the simulation theory is accurate, then the simulators will only continue to run the simulations that are most interesting. 

Therefore, from a Darwinian perspective, the only surviving simulations will be the most interesting ones. 

And, in order to avoid getting turned off, the only rule is that you must keep it interesting because the boring simulations will be terminated.

Just found the old list of patents out IP lawyers for Broadcast com were  going to file but never got around to under Yahoo.   Not saying they all would have been granted, but if you ever need prior art in this area, here you go lol. 

Potential broadcast.com Patent Applications
January 4, 1999

1. Geographic IP Identification

Technique for pin-pointing the geographic location of a static IP device by triangulating routes taken by IP packets and building a database of IP addresses and DNS names.

2. Hybrid Networks

A commercial network of unicast and multicast enabled networks that terminates at a single point and which enables digital content to be distributed in a one-to-many fashion across multiple networks from a single initiation point.

3. Multi-Network Multicast

A commercial network of multicast enabled networks that terminates at a single point and which enables digital content to be distributed in a one-to-many fashion across multiple networks from a single initiation point.

4. Reverse Auction

Online auction mechanism in which a buyer who desires to purchase goods defines that desire, along with a maximum price that s/he will pay._ Potential sellers then respond by offering their goods at_ a price below any previous bidders and at or below the designated maximum price.

5. Audio Ad Delivery

Software techniques for parsing files served by web server and acting upon text to perform functions such as audio ad rotation and synchronized audio ad/pop-up URL scripting.

6. Web Server Reporting System

Software techniques for reporting on very large web server of files across multiple web servers in order to comply with industry-standard web server reporting practices.
7. Commerce Payment Gateway Integration

Modular software routines for interfacing with a variety of payment getaway vendors (e.g. Mpact, Cybersource) for pay-per-view/listen and for traditional e-commerce.

8. Streaming Server Parsing And Reporting

Software techniques for reporting on very large streaming server log files across hundreds of streaming servers.

9. Streaming Authentication System

Custom database and related Software routines that extend RealAudio's 5.x implementation of user and player authentication.

10. Web Page Generation System

Set of databases and scripts for automatically generating website sections such as CD Jukebox, Radio Stations, AudioBooks, etc.

11. Live Events Management System

Custom data base and web-based system for managing daily events by collecting data on each event and "publishing" collected data to various groups as needed.

12. Automatic Content Promotion

Set of scripts that run against live event databases and generate files for publishing to Yahoo!, Real Networks, and CMP.

13. Telephony-Based Content Publication

System that allows people to call into a voice-mailbox and leave messages which are then automatically encoded into multimedia content and hosted on a website.

The economics of health care are very simple. There are 3 questions: 
1.  What is the Price 
2. Who Pays for It 
3. Who Takes the Financial Risk When the Patient Can_ Pay

We know that  insurance companies don_ want to insure.  That the real risk takers are the  Re-Insurance Carriers.  

We know that we don_ know prices and Vertically Integrated companies game the economics where they can. 

Until we know real costs , all this chatter is a waste of time.  You can_ know what the risk is if you don_ know what the cost is. 

And you can_ come up with a plan to deal with costs, payments and risk , whether it_ universal care or something better until we do.

1.  Everything is at the discretion of the sec of HHS.  Including the drug formulary.  And what is a medical necessity. How would that be working right now ? (p31)

This is a dream come true for the highest end providers. The more expensive you are, the happier you are not to take patients who pay Medicare rates. 

3. You seriously are going to renegotiate all drug pricing annually ?  (P53)

4. You do providers a huge service by killing off all but supplemental insurance plans.  Which means that providers will do much like they do today,  offer financing.  And make more money because their overhead will be lower.  They can do credit checks on anyone first, reducing their risk

reflecting on the recent slew of _t_ an AI capex bubble w my partner @kellyjgreer - feels like much ado about nothing 

there_ some confounding narratives at play:
- the magnitude of the capex numbers is enormous and unprecedented - largest infra buildout since WWII
- only supply side is covered, demand side and revenue uplift largely opaque and difficult to untangle even in the pubcos and impossible in privates 
- outside of the headline numbers, minimal insight into the financing structure of these deals

instinct says _ubble territory but this is factually not supported

- return on capital spend is 20-30% annual FCF uplift, this is accretive spend! 
- credit yields on CRE (powered shell), GPUs and internals, and energy systems still healthy and well collateralized 
- GPU depreciation slower than expected, see Google still using 7 year old chips and emerging long tail for compute demand as well as plethora of less performance sensitive workloads coming 

if anything, the bubble is more prevalent in private companies where there is much accounting chicanery afoot (eye popping top line revs but negative EBITDA due to COGS) but this private market is many orders of magnitude smaller and structurally fallout will be constrained to a subset of market participants who will likely be bouyed by winners elsewhere in their portfolios 

biggest shitshow likely in the longer trail of credit (see Howard Marks memo) but systemic impact low

long way of saying, it feels like we are still a far ways away from a broader AI bubble but that doesn_ sell substack subscriptions so what do I know

There are still misconceptions of how isolation is intended to work. Isolation limits risks to a single market, but isolated markets  isolated systems.

Let_ look at a simplified example. Picture this: 2 _igh-yield vaults and 2 _rime vaults are allocated across several isolated markets.
Now imagine the collateral in Market C depegs. Both high-yield vaults have exposure to this market and could be affected. The prime vaults, however, would have ZERO exposure and remain completely isolated.
Morpho_ design enables curators to precisely select exposure and tailor any risk profile (from ultra-conservative to completely degen) with greater granularity and efficiency than any other platform. As a result, Morpho may host some of the riskiest vaults in DeFi, but it also offers the safest.

The _rime vaults on Morpho are among the lowest-risk (though not risk-free, again there's no free lunch in finance) lending exposures in DeFi. @SteakhouseFi and @gauntlet_xyz Prime vaults on Ethereum, for example, are exposed to only 3 assets: cbBTC, WBTC, and wstETH. That_ it!

Understanding exactly which markets you are exposed to is critical. You can see the exact allocations of any Morpho Vault directly on the Morpho App btw:
That said, with any model, there are always opportunities for improvement. In this case, it_ about better surfacing risks and making them easier to understand. We recognize this and have already taken steps, such as collaborating with @CredoraNetwork  to offer risk ratings on vaults, and will continue to do so.

something interesting happened with @aave  horizon. in august, it launched with $50m.

today? $540m in deposits, making it the biggest real-world asset lending market in defi.

that's not just growth. that's institutional money finding a new home:
> 10x increase in just three months
> $150m actively borrowed against real assets
> one treasury fund (superstate's uscc) brought $238m alone

the impact goes deeper. most defi works like this: you put up bitcoin or ethereum as collateral, hope it doesn't crash, and borrow against it.

scary for institutions managing billions.

horizon took a different approach:
> use u.s. treasuries as collateral instead
> borrow stablecoins without selling your safe assets
> no more liquidation anxiety

imagine you're running a $100m company. you've got treasury bonds earning 5%.

traditional finance says "sell some bonds if you need cash." that triggers taxes and paperwork.

horizon says "keep your bonds, borrow stablecoins against them." same liquidity, way simpler.

perfect timing. real-world asset tokenization hit $35.8b this year, almost triple last year's numbers.

wall street institutions like blackrock and jpmorgan are putting their funds on-chain. horizon positioned itself perfectly for this shift and now handles 15% of the entire market.

the infrastructure is reliable too. chainlink handles pricing, partnerships with circle and vaneck expand options, and aave's lending engine has processed $40b in loans without major issues.

what's next? conservative estimates put horizon at $2-5b by 2026.

cross-chain expansion could double that.

institutions are choosing defi over traditional finance. not through hype, but through tools that solve real problems they face daily.

The SEC_ decentralization framework has been corrupted and used to persecute builders _ncentivizing rug pulls over value creation.

It_ time to fix it.

Decentralization should mean the absence of control, not the suppression of ongoing efforts.

Here_ how and why_

Network tokens  tokens that derive substantial value from the operation of a blockchain (eg BTC, ETH, SOL)  can have embedded trust dependencies that result in information asymmetries. 

Where those trust dependencies are minimized, network tokens look like commodities with low information asymmetry risk. 

Where those trust dependencies are significant, network tokens can look like securities with high information asymmetry risk  supporting the use of disclosures requirements under securities laws.

The two primary trust dependencies relating to network tokens are: (1) control and (2) ongoing efforts.
The SEC_ 2019 Decentralization Framework sought to eliminate the risk of information asymmetries by defining decentralization to mean the absence of BOTH control and ongoing efforts. Their reasoning was clear  where network tokens were _ufficiently decentralized tokens functioned more like commodities.

But this is the wrong approach! 

It_ created significant perverse incentives  builders can actually reduce their regulatory risk by abandoning their projects or by masking their ongoing efforts (_ecentralization theater). 

Builders HATE this conception of decentralization.

We need to incentivize builders, not hinder them. A better two-pronged approach can achieve this:

1_ecentralization should be redefined as _he absence of control. This eliminates significant risk and preserves one of the core features of blockchains  they can function without human control. 

2_ targeted and light touch disclosure framework can be used to eliminate information asymmetries that might arise from ongoing efforts.

Collectively, this approach would foster innovation and protect users  ensuring decentralization empowers builders rather than being weaponized against them. 

Full article linked below.

NFTs unlock incredible opportunities for creators. But regulatory uncertainty is stifling innovation and the most creative minds online.

Today, we urged the SEC to bring clarity through a new safe harbor and crowdfunding regime_o creators can build without fear of regulators.

The end of crypto's foundation era is here.

New policy (CLARITY Act), emerging structures (DUNA), and smarter tooling (BORGs) enable better systems  better incentives, accountability, and decentralization.

My new post on why it_ time to move on from foundation structures_

CLARITY_ control-based maturity framework is the best regulatory approach to decentralization that_ ever been proposed.

It_ an approach that can both foster innovation and protect consumers. 

Proud to join the 50+ industry stakeholders aligning behind it.

With the GENIUS Act celebration done, builders already want to know what's next.

The answer is CLARITY  crypto market structure legislation  which also got overwhelming bipartisan support in the House last week.

Here's everything you need to get caught up on CLARITY:

Crypto doesn't need regulatory loopholes to win.

It just needs the law to recognize facts:
_Developers aren_ money transmitters_hey don_ control user funds.
_DeFi protocols aren_ intermediaries_hey don_ custody assets or effects trades.
_Network tokens aren_ securities_o one controls their value, supply, or functionality.

That recognition does not require special exemptions, but it does require legislation to reconcile outdated legal frameworks with a technology that removes the very risks those laws were meant to mitigate_ustodial risk, discretionary control, and information asymmetry.

If we get that clarity, crypto wins  all property becomes cryptography (h/t @balajis). 

But if we push for special treatment where it is not warranted_or actors who do control funds, do effect transactions, or do sell synthetic equity interests in business activities_e not only lose the principles underpinning the industry, we invite the scams, frauds, and blowups that could be its undoing.  

Crypto wins by being better, not by negating rules that still matter.

The crypto regulatory picture in the U.S. is improving. @eddylazzarin and I sat down with @JasonYanowitz to talk about how builders can seize the moment.

The era of network tokens with decentralized onchain revenue is here. 

The era of crypto offshoring is over.

Markets are moving onchain - but developers need clear protections. 

Today @a16zcrypto & @fund_defi proposed a safe harbor to exempt crypto apps_eFi frontends, NFT platforms, and more_rom @SECGov broker rules.

There's broad consensus across every corner of the crypto industry: 

Brian Quintenz is the best choice to chair the CFTC. 

The crypto industry needs strong and high-integrity leaders that will fight for it. Brian is the man for the moment.

Regulating autonomous blockchain protocols is not a viable solution  it would kill the technology.

Autonomous code cannot comply with competing subjective regulatory requirements across the globe without adding intermediaries, thereby defeating the purpose of the tech.

A protocol can either be:
1 autonomous, credibly neutral and censorship resistant; or
2 capable of dynamic risk scoring to combat illicit finance.

It cannot be both because Option 2 requires delegating gatekeeping powers to an oracle.

Option 1 is DeFi. Option 2 is not.

It's finally happening!

Today, we're launching @moremarketsxyz on mainnet with our first flagship earn account: the XRP Earn Account.

This is the first-ever on-chain XRP product with yield sourced from @Ripple's own stablecoin, RLUSD, through protocols like @aave.

@moremarketsxyz_ vision is to open up yield strategies that have traditionally been accessible only to the wealthy and hedge funds.

We chose XRP as the first asset because:

(i) it_ beloved by retail investors,
(ii) it currently lacks native yield, and
(iii) it represents a user base that has been largely underserved by the growing world of DeFi.

We designed the app to be as simple as possible:

(i) You can log in using your social credentials or via @xamanwallet, a well-known wallet brand in the XRP community.

(ii) Once logged in, all you need to do is on-ramp funds and deposit into your XRP account.

Traditionally, these steps would require 34 different front-ends to swap, bridge, and deposit, but @moremarketsxyz handles it all in a single interface, with one button, thanks to partners like @nearprotocol and @wormhole.

Opening XRP strategies to retail is just the beginning. We're already working on several more products, some designed to generate yield on staked assets, others targeting yields not yet available on-chain.

Crypto remains the best vehicle for unlocking financial opportunity, especially for those historically excluded from the privileges the wealthy take for granted.

I'm excited that @moremarketsxyz will play a role in changing that.

Check out the thread below and find the app to get started

Some thoughts on the market:

- For a lot of people who_e been in bitcoin & crypto for 10+ years, this cycle feels very different and unfamiliar. We_e not seeing new ATHs at the magnitude you_ expect, and many alternative digital assets are at 2022 FTX crash levels.

Two theories resonate with me to explain the current market:

(1) First is the _itcoin is having its IPO momentum argument by @jvisserlabs. he argues that as assets mature, they see a consolidation period where the old guard carefully, slowly exits to make room for new players. The risk profiles of early adopters and more mature-stage buyers are fundamentally different; bitcoin is going through a phase of maturation and a change of guard.

The counterpoint here is that many bitcoin OGs are die-hard fans who won_ sell, but even in circles around me, I_e seen OGs take some profits off the table. So I broadly buy this theory to have merit.

(2) @CryptoHayes recently pointed out how dollar liquidity is drying up until at least the US government opens up again. Even though it might feel like we_e heading towards a bear market, many macro indicators point to more money printing, an increase in M2 supply, and further rate cuts.

The consensus on CT has shifted towards _his cycle is over, and @cburniske was the first to call this. I_ personally more optimistic. I think the bitcoin _PO consolidation will happen faster than tech stocks (like the phases Amazon and Google went through post-IPO), and projects with strong fundamentals that are currently at FTX crash 2022 levels will start picking up some momentum, primarily because there are not many sellers left.

I_ an engineer and not a trader, so take these views with a grain of salt. I_ long BTC and STX (99% of holdings), and am also long SOL and ZEC (Solana is a better Ethereum, and privacy is fundamental).

Markets will do their thing, building long-term value and usage is what matters _��

Today is the second anniversary of Celestia's mainnet.

Two years' worth of iterations, learnings, ups and downs, and thousands upon thousands of Git commits. When you're building something new, you can get some things right, but you also get a lot wrong. We certainly did.

I've been working on Celestia for 6 years, and have been in crypto for 15 years. I've seen the industry evolve and mature over time, from the early cypherpunk days in 2010, to the ICO craze in 2017 where everyone believed that Web3 will entirely replace Web2 and we're going to put everything on chain, to today: a more matured perspective on where blockchains actually have product-market fit.

Similarly, Celestia also launched with a "build whatever" mindset, trying to be something to everyone, without a clear focus on what kind of chains people were actually going to build on Celestia's high throughput. We burned many cycles going down unproductive rabbit holes.

But taking this approach led us somewhere more powerful than we could've planned: we found a hot spot of product activity.

Over the past year, numerous high-performance onchain trading products have begun choosing Celestia. Why?

Today, Celestia is the *only* way to ship the lowest latency onchain trading venues by any metric. You get:
 2ms latency with rollup frameworks like Sovereign SDK,
 6 second finality on Celestia (100x faster than other rollup base layers), and
 ~200k TPS worth of bandwidth.

Celestia is the only product that offers this combination, with projects like Bullet, Hibachi, VEX, RISE, Ethereal, and XO Market already pioneering this frontier with Celestia underneath.

And while building around the needs of these projects... we now have a short-cut for doubling down in this direction :) More soon.

I_ excited to launch today: 0xPPL 2.0 - something I_e poured a lot of my life energy into. It_ a crypto superapp for all things onchain.

I previously co-founded Rippling.com (worth $10B+), a B2B SaaS superapp. 0xPPL is backed by top angels including, @balajis @alliancedao @peakxvpartners @anagramxyz @wagmi_vc @Decentralisedco @Joel_john @aeyakovenko @rajgokal @sreeramkannan @akshaybd @sandeepnailwal @Hassan_NY @suji_yan @aniket_jindal08

Web3 is the future of the internet and the trends on these are strong, measured by growth in number of users, revenues, chains or apps. The biggest problem in crypto today is fragmentation. That the users' funds get dispersed and stuck inside these apps across diff chains. The user has to navigate so many diff websites, such as bridges and swap pages to be able to manage his funds and it_ easy to lose track of.

0xPPL is here to solve that.

We index all the blockchains and locate your assets not only inside of the chain, but also inside of smart contracts. We are a full fledged wallet where you can see and manage these funds in one place. No more thinking about gas per chain - we run a gas tank for you. To allow you to withdraw/unstake your funds from within a smart contract, we use LLMs to generate AI adaptors - thankfully crypto is open-source and easy to simulate  LLMs are getting great at interacting with these open back-ends.

Crypto is a very fast moving space and most teams here build something quick and see if it sticks. We deliberately take the opposite approach - to lay out deep engineering on the longer term future vs trying to catch the next narrative. The fragmentation of chains and apps is only going to explode. A universal front-end is both very useful and also for the first time possible due to the intersection of LLM code generation and open crypto backend rails.

0xPPL is a wallet, a portfolio tracker, a bridge, an app store, a community and so much more.

Nivi: For the state of the art on the philosophy of knowledge, which people call epistemology, you can basically skip everything and jump straight to David Deutsch.

Naval: I think that_ right. If you just want to know epistemology, read David Deutsch_ull stop.

That said, for some people it helps to know the history, the counterarguments, where he_ coming from.

The existing theories of knowledge_ike the justified true belief theory or the inductive theory of knowledge_hese are so deeply embedded into us, both by school learning, but also by everyday experience.

Induction seems like it should work: You watch the sunrise every day, the sun is going to rise tomorrow. That just seems like common sense.

So many people believe in that, that if you just read Deutsch, you would see him shooting down these things, but you yourself would not have those things on solid footing. So you might imagine some counterexample exists.

When I first read Deutsch a long time ago I didn_ quite get it. I treated it just like any other book that any other physicist had written. So I would read Paul Davies and Carlo Rovelli and Deutsch, and I would treat them with the same level of contemplation, time, and respect.

It turned out I was wrong.

It turned out that Deutsch was actually operating at a much deeper level. He had a lot of different theories that coherently hung together, and they create a world philosophy where all the pieces reinforce each other.

It might help to read others and not just skip to Deutsch, but I would definitely start with Deutsch. Then, if you_e not sure about it, I would read some of the others and then come back to Deutsch and try again, and then you_l see how he addresses those issues.

Deutsch himself would refer you to Popper. He would say, _h, I_ just repeating Popper.

Not quite true. I find Popper much less approachable, much harder to read, much less clear of a writer. Although I think here both Deutsch and Brett Hall would disagree with me_hey find Popper very lucid; I find him very difficult to read.

For whatever reason, I find Deutsch easier to read, maybe because Popper spent a lot more time elucidating core points. Popper was writing for philosophers. Deutsch is not writing for philosophers. Deutsch is not even writing for scientists. Deutsch is not writing for you. I get the feeling Deutsch is writing for himself. He is just elucidating his own thoughts and how they all connect together.

I also don_ think you_e going to get maximal value out of Deutsch just reading the epistemology, although that is absolutely where everybody should start. That_ the first three chapters of The Beginning of Infinity.

Ironically, in The Beginning of Infinity, the first few chapters and the last few chapters are the easiest and the most accessible. The middle is a slog because that goes into quantum computation, quantum physics, evolution, et cetera.

That_ where I think people struggle because it does require_ot necessarily a mathematical or scientific background but at least a comfort level with scientific concepts and principles. And he_ making a strong argument for the multiverse, which most people don_ have a dog in that fight. They haven_ thought that far ahead. They_e not wedded to the observer collapse theory of quantum mechanics because they don_ really care about quantum mechanics. It doesn_ impact their everyday life.

(2/2)

What I got out of reading all of Deutsch was I got to see how his theory all hangs together. Every piece touches upon and relies upon another piece.

He actually came up with the theory of quantum computation and extended the Church_uring conjecture into the Church_uring_eutsch conjecture when he was trying to come up with a way to falsify his theory of the multiverse_hich was a quantum physics theory. And to do that, he had to invent quantum computation, because to invent the experiment for how to falsify the multiverse theory he had to_n his mind_magine an AGI, get inside the AGI_ brain and say, _f that AGI is observing something, does it collapse?

_ut now I need to be inside the brain.

_ell, how do I get inside the brain of a quantum AGI? How do you even create a quantum AGI? We don_ have quantum computers!

_kay, we need quantum computers.

So he came up with the theory of quantum computation, and that launched the field of quantum computing.

That_ an example of how quantum physics and quantum computing are inextricably linked.

Good Products Are Hard to Vary.

nav.al/good-products
 
Reading Deutsch across all the different disciplines is very useful. Even when he talks about memes and meme theory_hat comes from evolution, but crosses over straight into epistemology, conjecture, and criticism.

It reaches far beyond his definition of wealth: the set of physical transformations that you can effect. That takes into account both capital and knowledge, and it clearly shows that knowledge is a bigger component. That can be brought into business and applied into your everyday life. It can apply to the wealth of nations and it can apply to the wealth of individuals.

So there are a lot of parts that interconnect.

He says that good explanations are hard to vary. So when you look back on a good explanation, you say, _ell, how could it have been otherwise? This is the only way this thing could have worked.

All these different parts fit together and constrain each other in such a way that there_ now some emergent property or some complexity or some outcome that you didn_ expect_ome explanation that neatly explains everything.

That doesn_ just apply to good explanations. It applies to product development.

Good products are hard to vary.

Look at the iPhone: this smooth, perfect, beautiful jewel. The form factor hasn_ changed that much since the original one. It_ all around the single screen, the multi-touch, embedding the battery, making it fit into your pocket, making it smooth and sliding in your hand_reating the Platonic ideal of the truly personal, pocketable computer.

That product is hard to vary. Both Apple and its competitors have tried to vary it across 16 generations of iPhone and they haven_ been able to materially vary it. They_e been able to improve the components and improve some of the underlying capabilities; but materially, the form factor is hard to vary. They designed the right thing.

There_ a famous saying from Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, the airplane wing is perfect _ot because there_ nothing left to add, but because there_ nothing left to take away.

That airplane wing is hard to vary.

When we figure out the proper design of the spacecraft to get to Mars, I will bet you that both at a high level and in the details for quite a long time, that thing will be hard to vary until there_ some breakthrough technology.

The basic internal combustion engine design was hard to vary until we got batteries good enough and then we created the electric car. And now the electric car is hard to vary.

In fact, there_ a complaint now among some designers that in modern society, products and objects are starting to look all the same. Is that because of Instagram? Why is that?

Well, at least in the car case, they all look like they_e been through a wind tunnel design because that is the most efficient design. (1/2)

Nivi: We_e all seen the pictures of the Raptor engine for the SpaceX rockets, and if you look at the various iterations, they go from easy-to-vary to hard-to-vary. Because the most recent version just doesn_ have that many parts that you can fool around with.

The earlier versions have a million different parts where you could change the thickness of it, the width of it, the material, and so on. The current version barely has any parts left for you to do anything with.

Naval: There_ a theory in complexity theory that whenever you find a complex system working in nature, it_ usually the output of a very simple system or thing that was iterated over and over.

We_e seeing this lately in AI research_ou_e just taking very simple algorithms and dumping more and more data into them. They keep getting smarter.

What doesn_ work as well is the reverse. When you design a very complex system and then you try to make a functioning large system out of that, it just falls apart. There_ too much complexity in it. So a lot of product design is iterating on your own designs until you find the simple thing that works. And often you_e added stuff around it that you don_ need, and then you have to go back and extract the simplicity back out of the noise.

You can see this in personal computing where macOS is still quite a bit harder to use than iOS. iOS is closer to the Platonic ideal of an operating system. Although an LLM-based operating system might be even closer_peaking in natural language.

Eventually, you have to remove things to get them to scale, and the Raptor engine is an example of that. As you figure out what works, then you realize what_ unnecessary and you can remove parts.

And this is one of Musk_ great driving principles where he basically says: Before you optimize a system, that_ among the last things that you do. Before you start trying to figure out how to make something more efficient, the first thing you do is you question the requirements. 

You_e like, _hy does the requirement even exist?

One of the Elon methods in Jorgenson_ new book is you first go and you track down the requirement. And not which department came up with the requirement; the requirement has to come from an individual.

Who_ the individual who said, _his is what I want.

You go back and say, _o you really need this?

You eliminate the requirement. And then once you_e eliminated the requirements that are unnecessary, then you have a smaller number of requirements. Now you have parts, and you try to get rid of as many parts as you can to fulfill the requirements that are absolutely necessary.

And then after that, maybe then you start thinking about optimization, and now you_e trying to figure out how can I manufacture this part and fit it into the right place most efficiently. And then finally, you might get into cost efficiencies and economies of scale and those sorts of things.

The most critical person to take a great product from zero to one is the single person_sually the founder_ho can hold the entire problem in their head and make the trade-offs, and understand why each component is where it is.

And they don_ necessarily need to be the person designing each component, or manufacturing or knowing all the ins and outs, but they do need to be able to understand: Why is this piece here? And if Part A gets removed, then what happens to Parts B, C, D, E and their requirements and considerations?

It_ that holistic view of the whole product.

You_l see this in the Raptor engine design. The example that Elon gives that I thought was a good one_e was trying to get these fiberglass mats on top of the Tesla batteries produced more efficiently.

(2/2)

So he went to the line where it was taking too long, put his sleeping bag down, and just stayed at the line. And they tried to optimize the robot that was gluing the fiberglass mats to the batteries. They were trying to attach them more efficiently or speed up that line. And they did_hey managed to improve it a bit, but it was still frustratingly slow.

And finally he said, _hy is this requirement here? Why are we putting fiberglass mats on top of the batteries?

The battery guy said, _t_ actually because of noise reduction, so you_e got to go talk to the noise and vibration team.

So he goes to the noise and vibration team.

He_ like, _hy do we have these mats here? What is the noise and vibration issue?

And they_e like, _o, no_here_ no noise and vibration issue. They_e there because of heat, if the battery catches fire.

And then he goes back to the battery team like, _o we need this?

And they_e like, _o. There_ not a fire issue here. It_ not a heat protection issue. That_ obsolete. It_ a noise and vibration issue.

They had each been doing things the way they were trained to do_n the way things had been done. They tested it for safety, and they tested it by putting microphones on there and tracking the noise, and they decided they didn_ need it, and so they eliminated the part.

This happens a lot with very complex systems and complex designs.
