EigenCloud being born in Seattle is not a coincidence. 

It is literally in the air. Home of aws and azure, and UW CSE where lots of the tech innovation happens. 

Our first COO @chrisdury was an exec at aws. Our first VP of engineering @siddsanyal was an aws engg leader.  @vishnu_patankar who now leads engineering and product at Eigen built Dynamo on AWS to scale amazon shopping traffic ~15 years back, which later became the foundation for DynamoDB. Our VP of marketing @jt_rose was a marketing leader at azure.

Excited to build and scale the crypto cloud.

EigenAI + EigenCompute for a verifiable world!

AI and Agents are extremely useful but cannot be trusted in high-value scenarios.

Models can be swapped, prompts modified, responses tampered. When billions of $ and real-world decisions depend on AI, blind trust is a bug.

EigenAI + EigenCompute fix this. 

Excited to share Google, Coinbase, Worldcoin_ Humans vs AI, Dapper Labs, ElizaOS, OpenRank, Collective Memory, FereAI, and OpenFront are among the first exploring what verifiable agents make possible with EigenCloud.

_ Verifiable agents: logic provably runs as written. @humansvs_ai of @worldcoin proves fair gameplay with 70k weekly users.

_ Insured agents: economic guarantees against failure. @fere_ai agents run for months without guardrails.

LayerZero ��_ EigenCloud: bridging with economic security. 

Why do you need economic security for a DVN? 
1) Disincentives: Any malicious behavior by the DVN operators is punishable by slashing. This creates concrete disincentives for misbehavior. 
2) Insured bridge: Over time this will be a fully insured bridge where every transaction is insured and if the operator is malicious, the users get their stolen value paid back. 
3) Starting small: we are starting with 3 chains and a small amount of stake but will expand this over time to cover other chains.

It has been a great thrill for us to work with @PrimordialAA and @MaybeMaxPower who have built a world class team at LayerZero. 

Thanks also to the @a16zcrypto team for their help with research on observability, finality and slashability to expand this across many chains.

Excited to speak about how the Ethereum ecosystem can solve AI_ biggest problems: 

1) Trust: as we delegate trust to ai agents, we need them to be trustworthy and verifiable.

2) Data attribution: We need mechanisms to identify data and IP contributors and reward them. 

3) Empower talent: there is a David vs Goliath moment in AI where a single ai company can eat up all of the economy. How do we arm the devs for rebellion? 

4) Democratize investment: The only thing left in a world with no talent premium is return to capital. That too is gate-kept massively: OpenAI will IPO at a couple trillion dollars. How can we democratize investment in the agentic era?

5) Decentralize gpu infra. 

6) Scaling laws: As much as frontier models need infinite compute, we also see open-source  achieve last years SOTA at 10-100x lower compute and cost. Good enough ai can be massively decentralized.

There are only two positive sum games (games that grow the pie):
Coordination and Innovation.

Coordination brings N people together to do more than the sum of the parts. Example: money, constitution, free markets, venture capital.

Innovation is the alchemy that converts a non resource into a resource. 
Example: convert air to spectrum, oil to energy, and silicon to intelligence. 

Both require risk taking: trying new things and failing often. But when they do succeed they have outsized returns. They create much more than they take, and thus grow the pie. 

To accelerate civilization we need to accelerate innovation and coordination. 

Technology automatically accelerates innovation, with AGI being the pinnacle of digital innovation.

Coordination is stuck in centuries old tech: money, constitution, and the Delaware C corp. Crypto is the new and ultimate accelerant of coordination: a system that is self-enforcing, automated, programmable and global. 

Crypto + AI =
Digital coordination + digital innovation =
Pinnacle of civilization.

_ Day 4 in New York. This morning at the @strobefund  Summit, @Raph_Bloch and I joined a panel featuring @PhilGPotter (@Tether_to cofounder) and @KashRazzaghi (@circle): a discussion that, as @AriDavidPaul said, brought together 95% of the stablecoin market cap on one stage.

Here are the main takeaways _

1�__ Money is going on-chain, and fast.
Kash expects a 1 million-fold increase in transactions as stablecoins mature. Cross-border transfers will be instant and almost free. Every form of money movement will eventually live on-chain.
Yet both he and Phil agree: usability remains the biggest barrier. Seamless UX is what unlocks the next wave.

2�__ Oversight will be crucial.
Phil warned that trillions of dollars moving globally, instantly, could trigger systemic or even geopolitical shocks. Scale needs governance, and speed needs control.

3�__ A winner-takes-most dynamic.
Both see little room for newcomers. Unless you_e part of a "powerhouse consortium", it_ nearly impossible to reach critical mass. Kash added: "we believe it_l be a one winner takes most of the market".

4�__ Tokenized deposits  stablecoins.
Kash emphasized that banks will probably go big on tokenized deposits, a theme we_e been exploring at @TheBigWhale_ with our clients, especially in our Q3 2025 briefing "The Institutional Dynamics of Stablecoins".

It_ clear the next phase of crypto will be shaped by how traditional finance integrates (not imitates) these new forms of money.

If there_ one recurring theme today at @strobefund summit, it_ UX. Whether it_ stablecoins or onboarding "normies", usability decides adoption.

During a panel with @_pgauthier (@Ledger) and @tyhunnny (@TYBXYZ) hosted by @fintechfrank, Pascal put it simply:

_ "Stop thinking tech first. Think product first. Tech should serve the user". Couldn_ agree more at @TheBigWhale_ 

Still, any compromise between ownership and UX must be weighed carefully: "It_ a critical moment in humanity to not let technology enslave us".

DeFi lending lives and dies by trust. One of the biggest mistakes is trying to compare DeFi lending with AMM pools because they work in completely different ways.

Lending only works when people believe the markets are sound, that collateral is solid, risk parameters make sense, and the system as a whole is stable. Once that trust breaks, you get the onchain version of a bank run.

That_ why a model where anyone can spin up a vault permissionlessly and market it on the same platform has built-in weaknesses. Since most strategies are already commoditized, curators don_ have many ways to stand out. They either lower fees to the bone or take on more and more risk to attract capital from other pools.

At some point, one big failure could wipe out confidence across the space and set the whole industry back. The next Terra Luna moment will come from a reckless curator on an open platform.

The core issue with the curation vault model lies in the illusion of isolation. Curators are meant to manage distinct strategies and segregate risk, yet in practice, they all end up supplying liquidity to the same underlying lending markets. What is designed to promote diversification instead concentrates exposure, turning one curator_ stress into everyone_ problem.

Despite being framed as modular and independent, the model inherently links all vaults through shared borrower pools. Liquidity from multiple curators merges into a single system, so the decisions or withdrawals of one can ripple instantly across all others as we see with recent issues with xUSD and similar assets. Even a cautious curator cannot escape the fallout from a more aggressive participant operating within the same pool.

When confidence falters or withdrawals accelerate, these shared markets seize up. Utilization shoots to 100%, redemptions grind to a halt, and borrowing rates spike to unsustainable levels. A localized liquidity crunch quickly transforms into a protocol-wide freeze, a DeFi version of a bank run essentially.

This creates a design paradox: a system built for isolation that, in reality, amplifies interdependence. Every vault inherits the risk behavior of the weakest curator, making the entire structure vulnerable when liquidity is most needed.

This model is even amplified by the economic design of these protocols: lower fees or take more risk to create business, otherwise become commoditized.

In contrast, Aave_ architecture achieves the risk segregation that curator models only promise. Each market operates in true isolation, with conservative collateral standards, controlled listings, and transparent onchain governance. Market shocks remain contained, liquidity remains accessible, and the protocol_ record of zero bad debt across billions in total value supplied underscores its resilience.

For vault creators and users, this difference is decisive. Shared-liquidity designs magnify contagion, while isolated-market frameworks contain it. Aave_ conservative design ensures predictable yields, reliable redemptions, and the stability that sustains confidence through volatility.

Some misconceptions and paradoxes in DeFi lending:

Lending is based on trust. This is the self-evident truth on which banking is built. Losing trust means losing capital, and that can cause bank runs or systemic collapses.

The way to preserve trust is to create a system that is fundamentally risk-averse throughout the entire supply chain. Ignore this rule and you are effectively in the business of risk-taking, which is more akin to today_ hedge funds.

DeFi lending protocols follow the same basic principles as banking. The fundamental difference between traditional finance and DeFi lending systems is that lending protocols encode trust mechanisms into the code for reasons like improving automation, capital efficiency, and liquidity provisioning etc.

Some people have a flawed idea that if a lending protocol fixes parameters around trust, it will somehow improve trust. Of course, this does not make sense since you are simply moving trust from one place to another. From one market level to another, but not really improving the trust assumptions, at all in fact.

You also cannot rely on fully immutable systems in dynamic marketplaces such as lending and borrowing. This is why comparing lending protocols to AMMs does not work either. Traders on AMMs do not depend on ongoing trust; their transactions are one-off trades, while borrowers and lenders maintain a relationship until the debt is repaid.
 
Applying immutable parameters means the system cannot adapt to changing market conditions, and financial markets are nothing if not dynamic. It_ relatively straightforward to run immutable model during up cycle, however bear markets is where the true resiliency is tested out.

Now, back to the idea of moving trust from one place to another.
 
Since trust always exists in lending, and most markets will likely rely on some level of human involvement, the real question is: at what level and under what circumstances should that involvement occur?

In isolated lending protocols like Aave, decision-making happens at the lowest level, close to the markets. This has benefits, such as ensuring that parameter decisions remain aligned with the protocol_ risk framework in a non-conflicted way. Risk managers are paid fixed fees to protect the protocol. If they fail, they get replaced, as we have seen before.

In designs where human involvement is moved higher up and risk curators are incentivized based on fund performance, hidden issues can emerge that are highly detrimental to the system.
 
First, the idea of risk curation as isolation is misleading. While markets may be separated, risk curators often share liquidity across markets by supplying to the same markets and comingling strategies. This means users can be exposed to the weakest curator or market in the system, with no capped protection.

For example:
 
Curator A supplies liquidity to markets B and C, while curator D supplies liquidity to markets C and E. If market E loses trust, for instance through a depeg event like xUSD or deUSD, it could trigger a bank run from market E, driving utilization to 100% and creating a race for withdrawals and even full insolvency.
 
At the same time, LPs withdrawing from the curated vaults cause another bank run at the vault level, meaning markets B and C are affected too. As a result, curator A_ LPs, even those subscribed to less risky strategies, would also be impacted, intensifying the liquidity contagion, even if they didn_ supply the liquidity into the problematic market, creating protocl-wide bank run.

This is my biggest concern with this type of design model: it leads to contagious liquidity effects that break trust while marketing some sort of risk isolation, which doesn_ in reality exist. It is especially problematic for RWAs, which require greater isolation due to their specific characteristics.

The problem worsens when considering curator incentives. DeFi risk strategies are highly commoditized. Lending against ETH or BTC is not particularly profitable or exciting for degens. So curators often go on the offensive, adding new types of collateral, sometimes untested or poorly understood. Other curators then rush to copy and allocate capital to these new markets.
 
It becomes a speed race to capture reward at the cost of additional risk, much like hedge funds today operate. It_ especially problematic for integrators that are looking to run their own strategies, knowing they would be commingled with strategies ran by riskier vault curators, making integrations more challenging.
 
Also this design comes at the cost of liquidity segregation, without truly improving or isolating risk, while introducing potential systemic contagion on every bank run. Given the permissionless nature, we will see more events of contagions spread.
 
It_ important for everyone to understand the mechanisms. DeFi is still relatively young, less than a decade old, and any large-scale issue could set the industry back significantly.
 
We are close to building safe and secure DeFi, and we need to protect the users. Hope this is a good learning on how to build better DeFi.

While in vault curator model there is no vetting process and typically risk management is centralized to a curator for good or bad.

Second, collaterals are limited with supply caps or even isolation mode where needed, so the markets can take limited exposure where it works, by pre-vetted risk management process, where each stakeholder are incentivized to ensure the market is not moving outside of the acceptable risk perimeter. This type of model builds trust and given the pre-vetting framework is more resilient compare to delegating the whole authority to a single entity, like a curator.

My concerns around the Uniswap Labs proposal:

While I appreciate Hayden_ and Uniswap Labs commitment to refocusing attention on the Uniswap protocol, and while that may be the right direction for them, I find that the proposal does not lead to the best outcome when applied more broadly across DeFi and other DAOs.

When a DAO has a genuine need for decentralized decision making, and this is typically the case for protocols with active parameters that must adjust to changing market conditions, such as lending protocols like Aave, decentralized governance becomes essential for protocol resiliency.

Resiliency is the key reason why many users and integrators trust Aave, and why Aave has become one of the most trusted DeFi protocols. The DAO has a pre-vetted, multi-stakeholder process that ensures no junk assets are listed and that the protocol does not take on more risk than it should. This approach has been proven across multiple market cycles, from the FTX crash and Terra Luna to several bear markets, the recent Black Friday, and last week_ events in DeFi.

Decentralized decision making can work very well when stakeholders have sufficient skin in the game and distinct expertise, allowing them to validate proposals and keep one another in check.

Second, true resiliency also means that if any stakeholder is removed from the equation, the protocol should still survive, continue growing, and create opportunities for new stakeholders to enter.

If there is a real need for resiliency, decentralized decision making works only when there are enough independent stakeholders. Without independent stakeholders, there is no real decentralization and no resiliency. Instead, decision making becomes concentrated, creating single points of failure.

To establish independence, each stakeholder should operate as its own business, with its own vision, mission, and balance sheet. Alignment can still be maintained by ensuring that all independent stakeholders have skin in the game.

The best way to ensure both independence and alignment or skin in the game is to build a business that either uses the protocol and helps scale its market share, or provides services to the protocol. This works because it creates the most capitalistic and incentive aligned scenario within a DAO. I am more bullish on the first path than the second, mainly because it is difficult to scale a business that relies on a single DAO. A service provider would typically need to support multiple similar protocols, which can introduce conflicts of interest.

I believe that if a DAO relies on one core entity, the outcome is far less efficient. The entity gains too much influence over the protocol, which reduces competition among service providers and results in higher costs for the DAO. If service providers and labs teams do not focus on building businesses on top of the protocol, the DAO becomes reliant on third parties with weaker alignment. This can lead to the underlying protocol becoming commoditized. If the protocol is fully abstracted away by the application layer, a third party has little reason to care about alignment when it can simply support multiple similar products and choose the lowest cost option. In contrast, having multiple stakeholders building successful businesses on top of a protocol, with real skin in the game, creates far stronger alignment.

Some may argue that a labs entity could simply build these services for the DAO. However, in that case, it becomes difficult for such an entity to compete with businesses operating in truly competitive capitalistic markets. This approach would likely result in mediocre products that are outcompeted by centralized teams with fewer governance constraints. It risks turning the labs entity into a grant driven organization with governance overhead, making it a less competitive acquisition layer for the protocol. In contrast, a model where aligned service providers build businesses powered by the protocol leads to higher market share, more competitive products, higher fees for the protocol, and more value for tokenholders. Protocols are meant to power businesses and products and to pursue the highest possible market share, and the best way to achieve that is through a fully competitive and capitalistic approach.

Another important point is why the DAO would corner itself into relying on a single core entity when it could instead place diversified and aligned bets with multiple teams. Also, why should the DAO sponsor the acquisition layer and take on venture risk to do so? This role should belong to service providers or entities building businesses on top of the protocol, using their and using their own balance sheet. The DAO and protocol should remain focused primarily on protocol development and fee management to ensure the highest outcome for tokenholders.

For yield bearing vaults, the ZK part becomes more important; you can include the pricing methodology in what you're proving. Hyperunit-style things work well when you have an oracle for a single asset vs. portfolio value function

In some ways, ZK perps DEXs (like Lighter) have an advantage for cross margin in that they don't really need something like Hyperunit at all since they're already natively processing proofs in both directions

But you're only lazily releasing the bridge lock where it only unlocks if a ZKP is received that you've been liquidated (so then it crosses a bridge) or a ZKP of non-liquidation (so you can withdraw it)
Bridges have fixed time lock and aren't "lazy"; this is lazy bridging (only bridging in the case of a valid ZKP of liquidation)
Yeah sort of; but you need to deal with the pricing of the vault too

It's close! But not quite the same (they don't do bidirectional withdrawal afaict; the perps use case really needs the liquidation to trigger bridge crossing. But I'd imagine you could modify this easily to handle that case)

Yes you lock on the source chain but only release the lock when the remote chain (perps dex) proves you were liquidated; the sequencer of the perps dex already is generating this proof so the relayer here is the sequencer

Well, you're already paying a liquidation incentive to either the third party liquidators or liquidation vault; you can include this into how you price the LTV. The advantage is that the remote vault is earning yield, so the collateral value is (generally) increasing which should offset tail costs (hence why the devil is in the details of setting LTVs)
Yeah exactly; the lender (e.g. perps exchange) needs to price in the duration risk into the margin req

You don't have to prove full execution; you only have to prove the liquidation condition is satisfiable; for custom circuit perps dexes like Lighter (no VM on the L2) this is extremely cheap! That's why I singled them out over general purpose / full VM proofs

Yeah, so the other side (the L2 that has a full VM), only has to prove the state of an escrow contract which holds the vault; as such you don't need full execution of the block, but rather just enough to construct the portfolio value for the block (which for lending vaults like morpho is updated infrequently enough that you don't have to have execution for every block to be accurate enough for a perps exchange offering margin)

I would be fine with a DA-based solution for checking on liquidation state consistency; seems fine but doesn't need the whole block execution state (especially for perps exchanges partitioned by pair)
no but it seems that in a world where DA bandwidth is plentiful this should be pretty easy to reconcile (and have client side verification of liquidation state for end users within their wallet)

Tokenized vault, like solver networks, needs liquidity to bootstrap; this doesn't require liquidity for the vault, only pricing a portfolio value for the vault (e.g. the oracle price weighted assets - liabilities + yield)

Yes, you lock the L1 vault position in a receipt token (but it need not be liquid, just an escrow)

I don't think this works because I need to wrap the liquidation condition (e.g. I need the proof from the L2 sequencer / DA layer that allows for withdrawal). This will use existing bridges but encumber the vault more so that its safe to use as collateral and/or I can compute an LTV easily

Yes, although lots of users have algorithmically closed positions (e.g. via a delta neutral strategy on the L2) and this allows you to not have to maintain this manually across the bridge; the other thing you have to consider is withdrawal requirements on the vaults on the L1

They don't need to trust the perp dex; if the DEX operator withholds a withdrawal proof, they can generate it from DA; this proof doesn't need to be a full block proof, just proof of "not liquidated + can close position", which force closes a position

Notably, force closing of a position has less damage than forced inclusion in L2 (since it won't reorder other txns and is appended at the end)

A myopic way to view them is as NFTs with more convenants (e.g. lock-up periods, 4626 or Pendle PT/YT style splits between principal and yield, etc.)

However, if you read vault contracts you will see there is far more intricacy into how you should price the portfolio value of the vault (which is the main factor going into margin calculations); so "it's just a bridged NFT" misses all of the actually important EV and risk calculations needed to make this a win over "I withdraw from vault, then bridge spot, then open position"

Yeah but the point if you want to encumber the ability to bridge or not by a dynamic condition (e.g. PV(t) < MaintainanceMargin(t); PV(t) = price of vault on source chain, MaintainanceMargin(t) = LTV/margin limit on L2. Both of these can change; the ZKP guarantees the invariant holds even if the state in the computation of PV(), MaintainanceMargin() changes)  this is beyond the standard EIP712/1155 paradigm

That is the point! There is effectively *always* cross-vault margin going on since the vault positions are changing (another reason I think you should read vault contracts)

Not really, you need both parties to validate an invariant that is changing, not a static one. This is much closer to peer-to-peer lending, because the perps exchange is effectively offering you a loan on your remote collateral

The main difference here is the L2 can liquidate the L1 position with a proof. A normal L2 bridge involves burning an L2 position and withdrawing from the L1 contract; the liquidation that the L2 does might still keep the assets in the L1 bridge contract (e.g. it might simply take sell spot on the L2). 

This is an ownership transfer from the L2 user who was liquidated to the L2 sequencer on the L1 that the L2 can force with a proof of liquidation versus a mint and lock (deposit) / burn and transfer (withdraw). It is also possible that the liquidation immediately starts an auction (a la Maker) on the L1 given a valid proof; this can be viewed as a transfer from the liquidated user to an escrow contract.

Normal withdrawals are the same (except that the L2 / app is proving more conditions related to the app state, such as non liquid-tability).

I always liked the idea of calling it _azy bridging or _ust in time bridging since you only bridge on a worst case event (liquidation) versus an average case event (post collateral)
Trust is *always* a worst-case property, yet users always pay for average case things; not having to explicitly bridge unless liquidated = better UX / fees / etc.

Right now, every position you open involves you bridging (which means you forego yield on the remote chain that you bridge from); here you only bridge when liquidated

This is basically remote collateral management where the ZK acts as a mutex

One main difference here (and this is from an app UX standpoint), is that if you have a yield-bearing vault that, even when tokenized, is not particularly liquid (e.g. due to withdrawal requirements or non-atomic deposit/withdrawal semantics), then you can't "deposit" it directly in the way you do with stETH. 

Think about the early days of DeFi, where people would have WETH on mainnet and WETH on an L2 and the liquidity differences led to huge mispricings when liquidations occurred; for these less liquid vaults (which are become far more popular now), you need to prove more properties of the assets locked in escrow (e.g. bounds on portfolio NAV) than you do for a receipt token that is liquid

So if you zoom out, "it looks like an L2's mutex-like locking;" but if you look at the practicality of using "remote" assets as collateral when they aren't super liquid when tokenized but provide non-atomic withdrawals, then there are a number of nuances

Another important difference, in my opinion, is the conditional bidirectional bridging. For instance, in the case of a liquidation, the L2 can "force withdraw" from mainnet to the L2. This is, in many ways, the opposite of how bridges work, where all of the forced inclusion logic is on the L1. The goal here is to a) allow certain conditions to allow bridging in a particular direction and b) define those conditions in a way that is safe for the user's funds AND exchange (L2) solvency and c) easy for intent solvers to satisfy

A proof is generated given DA that proves they were liquidated on the L2 application which the escrow contract validates and then allows a solver to claim the collateral from mainnet and bridge to the L2 to a liquidation contract (an auction, for example) that executes a sell order on the exchange to close out the liquidation

Who generates that proof?
1) sequencer (is not CR but with the right liquidation parameters, is incentive compatible)
2) solver network (a natural thing for solvers to do is to try to generate proofs to get a liquidation bonus)
3) prover network (provers act as canaries watching for liquidations and autogenerating proofs and submitting to mainnet to force liquidation)

Only thing that matters is that the L2 DA is around for the proof to be generated; this proof is much smaller than the full proof of correctness of the chain (c.f. lighter_ circuits; you only need to prove a single order book_ state update created a liquidation)
It_ wrapping non-atomic assets that are easy to price via oracle but not LP/DEX (e.g. Morpho vaults); and yes, the same could go the other way!

I_e been thinking abt this a lot and assumed people had moved beyond a 
boolean risk model but lol I was super wrong.

Losses will happen. From idiots and from exploits.

0 loss / 0 risk is not a thing. The probability of a thing happening is not knowable unless the things are defined.

First step is to define and measure the things. 

Namely: any loss incident should be
- rare
- bounded
- contained (fast, automatically)
- remediated (fast, transparently, fairly)
- not contagious!!!

How do you measure that shit? Yeah I dunno. Good luck man.

- Max single-incident loss amts
- Exposure / counterparties / dependency limits (if a single token going under = 100% TVL loss = you_e fucked)
- Time to detect / contain (automated)
- Time to detect / contain (manual, SLO_)
- Effectiveness of containment (if the token goes bye bye but you_e already fucked then containment doesn_ matter)
- Some measure of blast radius
- Total unmitigated worst case contagion loss amts 
- Ring-fenced asset amt for immediate remediation of losses (can go towards limiting contagion too)
- Some measure of risk acceptance (we accept the risk of giving all our money to a kid and have no way to detect or contain losses there)

It_ a mass value extraction + destruction event.

1. The incentive to fork by any entity in a particular position of power or control or advantage is extremely high. Historically this is almost entirely CEX_ as they control the creation and distribution of new markets. Today it_ more complex.

2. It_ doesn_ actually create 2 new economies, it splits value across 2 economies in an unpredictable and chaotic way. In doing so, neither economy is as valuable as the sum of its parts, and some amt of value also peaces out completely. Ultimately everyone loses. However, if you can come out ahead of in value redistribution, you will still do it. Incentives.

3. If the risk or perception of a fork occurring becomes too high, faith in the underlying protocol and assets diminishes. Liquidity dries up, less value is created as overall risk increases which impacts risk tolerance which impacts capital flows, value is destroyed when capital moves out of the ecosystem bc markets become weaker and more inefficient which introduces more risk and on and on.

Stablecoins absolutely control the fork choice. However, they aren_ necessarily incentivized to cause a fork or potential fork. I would say the likelihood of a fork happening on BTC is greater than ETH and SOL and that_ solely due to where the stablecoins live.

Their incentives could change though, most likely in reaction to an external event or change of circumstances that creates risk for the stablecoins. If at that point they deem it to be less risky to push for a fork that stay neutral, they will do so, because they control the fork choice which means they can derisk their own losses that would come from a fork, and they will do so even if it_ at the expense of others and the value of the ecosystem.

Ultimately what Ameen and others are commenting on is the broader meta-issue around incentives and alignment.

These words have well understood definitions within the theoretical research community. But those folks have less understanding of the broader market and value creation on the whole.

Meanwhile the broader market and those creating new value by taking on risk loads of risk have no fucking clue what those words mean they just think they are inherently valuable. (Spoiler: they aren_)

Thus the conversation and motivations and understanding of priorities get mucked up. Disagreements happen. Respect and trust erodes. Etc.

Solana is better than Ethereum at avoiding this sort of muck. But only bc it doesn_ much have a theoretical research community. Worth noting that less muck does NOT necessarily ensure better outcomes. It just means it_ easier to arrive at any outcome.

Anyways.

Alignment means that entity 1_ incentives match entity 2_. This is only valuable to consider bc it decreases the risk for entity 2. It also makes theoretical risks easier to define, understand, and thus mitigate (theoretically)

e.g. If a stablecoin is incentivized to malign Ethereum for its own gain, even if that gain adversely impacts the value of Ethereum, it should be expected that it does so.

Assuming Ethereum_ goal is to not be maligned and not have its value adversely impacted, it should obviously prioritize mitigating that risk.

How it ultimately prioritizes mitigating such things depends entirely on 2 things and none are the actuality of the risk (lol) 
1. It depends on the people who do thing_ perception of the risk relative to all their other perceptions about all the other risks 
2. It depends on their perception of their own ability to mitigate it and their perception of the effectiveness of their mitigations relative to their perceived effectiveness of other mitigations of other perceived risks.

Ameen thinks it_ stupid to prioritize FOCIL as it_ not actually effective at mitigating the risk of a fork bc that decision is ultimately on the stablecoins. He_ not wrong.

Researchers think it_ important to prioritize FOCIL because it impacts the overall power structures of various parties which could impact viability of a fork being induced (I think) but also other censorship things. Most likely the priority comes from the reality the researchers don_ have any clue how to incentivize the stablecoins to choose the right fork bc they have no way to define _ight and don_ perceive themselves to have influence over the application layer. They_e (probably) not wrong on some of that and unable to know they are super wrong on the rest unless you wish to upend their entire view of reality in a way that would eliminate their value as theoretical researchers on the whole (which I think is probably a bad plan bc research and especially irrational theoretical research has a lot of value even if it creates some muck.)

The only people who need to be concerned about a fork on a protocol with significant RWA value on it are those who_ value is impacted when that protocol_ value draws down by over 50% in the very short term, diminishes significantly (30%-70%) in short term, and potentially goes to ~0 in the longer term.

We asked @katie_haun from @HaunVentures about the fundamentals of crypto investing.

"Everyone told me it was a terrible idea to start a crypto fund."

"We see a market story and a technology story in crypto. The tech story is only changing for the better."

"This is largely due to builders building through the bear market. It's now <$0.01 to do a stablecoin or NFT transfer."

"There's also product-market-fit. Bitcoin is Exhibit A. Stablecoins are now the story of the day that folks in the mainstream are talking about."

"The last fundamental is regulatory. For the last decade, people from enterprises and institutions kept saying crypto will get shut down (but it didn't happen)."

"The bill passed through the Senate. Great news."

"I feel similarly to when ETFs for Bitcoin and ETH were approved. The courts unanimously said the SEC acted arbitrarily."

Chamath: China Isn_ Rising, It_ Re-Ascending __

_ don't think China is a rising power. I think China is a re-ascending power.

_nd the reason I say that is, if you go back to 1500 to now, over all of those years, China had the world's largest GDP 70% of those years.

_f you think about it in that context, especially as a Confucian society, I think the Chinese think about this as, _old on, this is reasserting the dominance that we've always had._

_he other interesting thing, which I learned studying China, is how they allocate capital.

_he capital allocation system is both rigid, but it's incredibly flexible. What do I mean?

_ou have Xi Jinping and his close circle of people, they dictate the priorities, right?

_i is personally right now helping to draft the five year business plan of China.

_ut what happens is, it goes from that central group of like 7, 8, 9 people, to the Politburo, and when it gets approved by the Politburo, it gets sent to all the provinces and then it gets sent to the prefectures.

_o an example was in 2006 and 2007 when they decided to prioritize EVs.

_hat you effectively have is a cascading set of venture capitalists who are operating against a national priority and then they are rewarded for it.

_nd so you essentially have 300 VCs running around organizing human capital in all of these different provinces against all of these different priorities.

_nd at the end of that you get a BYD, or you get a Xiaomi, or you get these great companies.

_nd I think that is what's so daunting if you think about it.

Friedberg:

_ think gambling generally, as we call it, should be decriminalized.

_nd I don't like this state-by-state set up with gambling.

_ think we should have a federal regulatory body.

_his is not going away. People love to bet on stuff. This is part of sports, this is part of the culture.

Chamath:

__ook at Polymarket.

_olymarket raised at, whatever it was, $1-2B at $9B. Then the next weekend they announced sports betting and now they're raising money 30 days later at, allegedly, $12-15B.

_nd you can see, by the way, the way that DraftKings and FanDuel stock have reacted to this, those companies are toast.

Friedberg:

__he Polymarket model is the best model because it creates a market.

_nd so as information flows in, that market will dynamically adjust and everyone will get a more fair price.

_olymarket actually has the news before the news does.

_nd this is one of the most powerful outputs of Polymarket, is they're actually getting a read on what's going on in the world before the media recognizes it, before the public recognizes it.

_hen you put money up, it actually turns out that when people have incentives, that market will find the truth.

"The trenches" was never a sustainable model. It was a moment, and the moment has passed. That doesn't mean there won't be liquidity injections in the future and another flare up of chasing 100x's on the daily for a bit, but those times are destined for a few special times, not the status quo.

The reckoning has been a long time coming, since before most participants today even discovered crypto, long before the trenches existed. You remember October 10?. That crash hit hard. @binance  liquidity just vanished. Over 1.7 million accounts liquidated. Nineteen billion dollars gone. 

Trump's tariff news sparked it. But Binance froze. APIs failed. Traders locked out. Stops never triggered. Bitcoin dipped to $102,000 on Binance spot. Coinbase held at $105,000. Kraken near $104,500. Small gaps. Big signals.

$ATOM suffered worse. #Cosmos  token flashed to $0.001 on #Binance. Zero liquidity. No mercy. @coinbase  stayed at $2.54. Stablecoins depegged there too. USDe to $0.66 on Binance. Others barely moved. Thin books met glitches. Exploits slipped through. The whole market lost $560 billion. You felt trapped if you traded there.

All of this goes on as @brian_armstrong  and others in crypto are trying to put into place a framework for the USA and abroad for clarity in crypto.

How on earth can Binance not have anything to answer for here?

Where are the voices to put pressure on getting to the bottom of this. I didn't get hurt during the crash because I don't trade with Binance but how can we possibly just ignore the giant elephant in the room and move on as if nothing happened?

People need answers and the market needs clarity, without it this market will honestly struggle to be more than just a place where people gamble and hope the exchange they work with doesn't just dog them and offer a $25 voucher.

Oct 10 Crypto Massacre: Binance Edition

The most important microstructure fact from the October 10th crypto massacre isn_ just _olatility was high and we had chain congestion, it_ that the reference/pricing/quotes many desks and DEXs lean on became unreliable, exactly when everyone needed it most. 

As it stands today, I am cautious to make acquisitions on what the root cause was. It is easy to point fingers at Binance right now but I don_ think that is justifiable, yet. The timing of depegs and initial cascade is still being looked into.

This is subject to change with more info. 

However, for us onchain users, the main issue was that Binance prices their wrapped assets at spot market price and not underlying value price. This is a known flaw that many borrow/lend protocols have identified, such as Solend and Aave, and is the reason many loopers were largely okay. 

Using secondary market pricing as an oracle for a token backed by real dollars (or SOL with an LST) makes no sense -> given the market price != the real price.

Crypto has too many venues, so why should the Binance market for USDe be the bearer of truth when in reality USDe is always backed by real value. The mint/redeem price should be the bearer of truth not Binance. 

Binance_ unified-margin stack was marking key collateral (USDe, BNSOL, wBETH) off its own spot order books. In the dislocation, those local markets detached from underlying value, WBETH printed in the $400s at one point while ETH itself traded multiples higher, and USDE/BNSOL also plunged on Binance versus external venues. Quoting for USDE was terrible and essentially caused anyone who was long an asset with usde as the collateral to get liquidated.

Okay, so if Binance was a big contributor to the mass liquidations onchain, how did Binance cause me to get liquidated on other perp DEXs?

Because in crypto perps, fair value is synthesized from a small set of anchors, and Binance is still the heaviest anchor. Most perps, CEXs and DEXs, blend top-venue spot feeds and many DEX oracles ultimately reference those same feeds. 

When the largest venue_ API stalls, Binance, and its local spot marks misprice wrapped collateral, two things happen in the market maker (MM) stack: (1) inventory and margin models start screaming false signals (your collateral is supposedly worth 4080% less when it is not), and (2) the external _id used to place quotes, skew sizes, and choose venues no longer feels trustworthy. 

With no defensible mid, MMs do the only rational thing: pull size, push their quotes way back, or go dark entirely until they can recompute risk. 

This is why some perp DEXs, those that held up better than others, still couldn_ fill some users bids. There were no market makers willing to quote. That gap shows up to end users as _preads went crazy and _an_ get filled, even on DEXs that did remain online. It_ not that no one wanted to make markets; it_ that you can_ price what you can_ mark. 

In a unified-margin regime, collateral marks flow straight into the math for liquidation thresholds. If WBETH is valued off a thin, dislocated spot print rather than its redeemable ETH value, your cross-portfolio buffer can vanish in seconds, even if your directional book is fine. 

This is why many basis (delta neutral) traders still got wrecked, especially those with high leverage as they quickly learned about ADL.Forced liquidations then hit books already thin on the bid, pushing prints further from fair and propagating the error into everyone else_ _ndex via cross-venue references, which sounds good in theory, but as explained above, is flawed when the leader goes bust. 

From a market maker_ (MM) point of view, the decision tree was brutal but quite an easy decision. Try to make a market but risk going bust or pull liquidity?

When your collateral present value (PV) and cross-venue mid diverge from reality, value at risk (VaR) explodes and your kill-switches trip. 

This compounded with API/chain congestion, wallet throttles, and venue halts. MMs often couldn_ move collateral or lay off basis even if they noted the mispricing and wanted to get out. This is why some MMs fared better than others. 

Lastly on MMs, contrary to CT, market making in that type of environment is massively -ev for these market makers. That_ why many desks yanked liquidity late, widening spreads further, and lived to re-enter once feeds normalized and collateral marks were patched. 

On venue performance: it_ fair to note @HyperliquidX  remained up (users are still hot about ADL), @Lighter_xyz  was down for ~4.5 hours, @tradeparadex was down for ~1 hour, and several centralized venues had intermittent issues amid the cascade. 

But uptime really isn_ the primary point here. It is reference/pricing/quote integrity and microstructure flaws on Binance_ side and other venues over-indexing on Binance_ prices. How is a team, Binance, that has been in the industry for 8 years still mispricing assets?

They price their wrapped assets at spot market price and not underlying value price. Marking them to thin spot prints instead of underlying redemption value is a first-principles error. 

If the system_ _rice of record is wrong, the rational market-maker response is to just pull all liquidity, which is smart for them, and even the best-engineered matching engine can_ conjure fills out of risk-model uncertainty. 

Zooming out: could a big Binance-focused MM have gone belly-up? I think so. The combination of (a) collateral PV shock from mis-marked wrapped assets, (b) inability to mobilize margin, and (c) stale/broken APIs is exactly the recipe that flips well-behaved delta books into forced-liquidation machines. 

We_l know more when desks publish their post-mortems; for now, my opinion is that this largely stems from Binance.

Last, on near-term flow and the macro overlay: Monday and Tuesday pose serious mark-to-market risk for traditional funds, as dealers who manage margin will need to crystallize losses. A surprise détente headline can always rip risk higher and, perversely, with a large cohort of six- to eight-figure crypto traders now structurally sidelined, the pain trade may indeed be up. 

However, I also see the other side: _ey, the market puked; I_ piling all my cash in for the meteoric rise and a resumption of _p-only season,_ only to watch the wick get filled in the direction no one wants to see.

Either way, I think in order to step into the market with bids in a meaningful way you need to assume Trump and Xi laugh it off and shake hands, which who knows, might already be happening.

Increase benchpress, reduce latency

Respectfully disagree with Matteo  I think there are sound points, but some important nuance is missing.

---

1. Latency is always a race to zero

Traditional HFT operates in the nano- and microsecond realm. No current blockchain  not even @megaeth_labs (10ms) or admittedly @bulletxyz_ (3ms)  comes close. The idea that an execution layer can fully eliminate _tate delta through FIFO processing assumes an ideal that doesn_ exist in real markets.

> _f the execution layer is performant enough to process everything FIFO then prioritizing cancels no longer makes sense.
This isn_ quite right.

The race isn_ between order placement and execution, but between the MM_ cancel and the taker_ fill  and even a few ms head start makes all the difference. In TradFi, HFTs purposely obscure their true latency to retain a _eserve edge when caught. Latency asymmetry is the game.

---

2. Fairness vs Liquidity Bootstrapping

DeFi isn_ TradFi. The biggest challenge today isn't fairness  it_ liquidity. TradFi exchanges are mature, with deep books and robust price discovery. DeFi isn_ there yet.

That said, it's false to argue _asdaq doesn_ have speed bumps, so toxic HFT must not be an issue. In fact, smaller TradFi venues like IEX and CHX introduced speed bumps precisely to combat these dynamics.

The HFT arms race is real in traditional financial markets:
* HFT flow accounts for ~20% of volume 
* Raises liquidity costs by 17%
* Makers win the cancel race just 13% of the time [1]

---

My take? We can and should have both.

DEXs must attract deep liquidity to compete with CEXs. That requires protecting MMs from toxic flow while enabling efficient execution. We_e already seen success here  Hyperliquid users accept its reordering logic, because it enables tighter spreads and better fills via MM _ast look advantages.

That_ why @bulletxyz_ is designed to do both:

* Low-latency (ms-level) execution
* App-specific sequencing

This is hard to do on general-purpose L1s  but necessary if we want DeFi to scale competitively.

[1] academic.oup.com/qje/article (h/t @MaxResnick1 )

Do not delay climbing mountains. If you have even a remote desire to climb mountains, you must act now.

That means committing wholeheartedly in the act of climbing. Which accordingly means sacrificing comfort, security, and the illusion of control at the altar of exposure, suffering, and the cold indifference of stone.

Codependence is not a pathology; it is the rope team.
It is not weakness but a form of transcendence.

Interreliance and relinquishment of self are more satisfying than any _ummit selfie or solo achievement.

Apotheosis of the self can only end in a vacuous narcissism held aloft on the capricious approval of strangers in the comments.

Embrace the void, the vertigo, and the possibility of failure.
In the death of ego, you will find a strange and ineffable joy 
the quiet communion between human and mountain,
where you are no longer climbing,
but being climbed.

Major crypto derivatives markets should have circuit breakers. Allowing a flash crash to blow up a significant percentage of your users is strictly value destructive. 

But if the exchange is left with bad debt which would have been liquidated if not for circuit breakers? That is what exchange insurance funds are for. Binance has a $1B "SAFU" insurance fund which akaik they haven't touched. All the major derivatives platforms print money and have large balance sheets. They should use this to protect users from this type of market failure.

Most users have more collateral to post if they have time to react. Most users would do a better job deleveraging their positions than the indiscriminate liquidation engine. 

Time also creates the opportunity for arbitrageurs to fix large market dislocations like the USDe price hitting 65c on Binance even though the Ethena protocol remained fully collateralized and mint/redeem functionality remained operational.

Privacy is the precondition for many of our freedoms. It_ the point at which government and corporate reach end and our individual freedoms and self-sovereignty begin. As our lives have moved online, privacy_ become a rare, vanishing commodity.

That_ why we founded Cypherpunk (@cypherpunktech)  a company dedicated to privacy and self-sovereignty. We will execute on our mission by accumulating, building, and supporting privacy-protecting assets and technologies at a time when the world needs them more than ever.

To that end, Cypherpunk  Ticker: $LPTX (today), $CYPH (tomorrow)  was launched with a $50 million+ investment from @winklevosscap to begin accumulating Zcash ($ZEC) at what we believe to be a significant discount to Zcash_ true long-term value. Since Zcash_ launch 9 years ago, we_e observed its highly symbiotic relationship with bitcoin. I think all stablecoin issuers assumed yield will necessarily be passed back to consumers. Just look at Coinbase - we're passing back yield on USDC held on Coinbase AND ALSO onchain. 

It's not stablecoin issuers that are afraid, it's banks. They're the ones most vulnerable to consumers holding their own dollars while earning a fair yield on those dollars. Our highly leveraged financial system exists on the premise that consumers are locked into holding their funds at banks, on which banks pay close to zero interest, while making loans and other efforts to generate yield on those dollars for themselves. 

It's the exact same reason the federal government hasn't allowed narrow banking whereby a bank takes in deposits and just holds all funds at the federal reserve, without making any loans, thereby creating incredibly safe and stable banking for consumers. 

This isn't about consumer protection. It's about protecting entrenched interests and also preserving the ability of the federal reserve to monkey with interest rates and other risk parameters to control the economy.

It was a privilege to join @NIHDirector_Jay for a wide-ranging conversation earlier this week.

The @NIH is the largest biomedical research funding body in the world  it_ a remarkable American asset, the source of so much therapeutic innovation, and I hope it continues to get even better in coming years.

This is not a political post. *Everyone* wants better health. 

I am an extremely grateful product of NIH funding - via the extraordinary MSTP (MD PhD) program, a steady fuel that has supported young biomedical research trainees for over 60 years in this country. I was, am, and continue to be a *huge* fan of what Director Francis Collins and many others achieved at the NIH. He oversaw our transition from the early days of human genetics to human genomics, to precision medicine (launching @AllofUsResearch), to extraordinary strides in cancer research, and much more.

And now we have a new NIH Director: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya. I took his undergrad health economics class at Stanford as a student nearly 20 yrs ago (!), and felt super fortunate to sit down with him this week to better understand how he thinks about go-forward priorities at NIH.

I found his vision compelling. He was transparent, direct, and clear. The NIH essentially has two big mandates: (1) fund allocation (deciding what major areas to fund, in what relative magnitudes), and (2) grant execution (selecting individual recipients, oversight of research over time, etc).

On (1), he wants to make sure the NIH is appropriately prioritizing ROI against the most common diseases in America: diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular disease, COPD, kidney disease, Alzheimer_, cancer, etc. He also believes NIH should respond with research in areas where disease prevalence has recently changed for reasons we don_ fully understand (eg autism).

On (2), he wants to enable the NIH to take bold risks, fund science that might fail, and encourage more young investigators to enter academia and science  because the current environment concentrates research $ in the hands of a few established labs, and leaves bright new people scrambling to yet another post doc if all their science doesn_ _ork. Everyone who_ ever spent time in academia knows there_ truth in that reality, but perhaps we haven_ yet known how to propose solutions. (The birth of multiple philanthropically-funded institutes have been one response).

Director Bhattacharya cares about academic freedom. Please listen to the conversation  we discussed (and agreed upon) the importance of evidence-based vaccines. We had a spirited debate about whether Americans should be empowered to defer to experts (at HHS, CDC, FDA, etc) on topics about their healthcare versus exercise their own choice. We probably don_ have exactly the same opinion on this topic, but that_ OK because we were granted the opportunity to engage in a civil debate.

So, consider listening. Listen if you are optimistic about biomedical science in America, and listen *especially* if you_e had skepticism about its future. Bring an open mind, form your own views, look for opportunities to express your feedback, and continue to debate. In the meantime, I remain incredibly excited to see continued innovation here in the US, and meet the brilliant investigators that NIH will boldly fund.

Thank you @NIHDirector_Jay, @eriktorenberg, and @JorgeCondeBio for the discussion.

Aren't the IO arguments for vertical integration basically the same thing as the thesis of the People's Republic of Walmart?

Namely, I remember the book arguing that the success of large well-integrated corporations is proof that they're more efficient than having market relationships between different parts of the supply chain, and so we should just have government-run structures that have the same style but serve the public interest instead of shareholders.

Intuitively, if you take horizontal monopolies as given, then vertical integration does make things less bad, because at least you avoid the "get permission from N of N different kings" problem. (eg. the hardware space has a lot of this N-of-N-different-kings issue) The economic argument within that context has always seemed sound to me.

The solution is to not take horizontal monopolies as given.

(Or, if you are inclined the other way, take the People's Republic of Walmart route and do a full-stack democratically-controlled monopoly. Which of course our economies already do in some sectors, and it's worth noting that a major source of failures in the public sector the last couple of decades comes from it losing a lot of overhead to consulting firms, the farmed-out nonprofit sector, etc - so basically horizontal monopoly without vertical integration)

Well the essay is a separate argument from the tweet _

I think the argument in the essay hinges on an optimism about political systems that I don't share at all. The various human rights and economic development people I talk to and listen to tend have an opposite perspective: in the 2020s, relying on rich people's sympathy has hit a dead end, and if you want to be treated humanely, you have to build power - and the nicest form of power is being useful to people.

The right point of comparison is not people collecting welfare in rich countries like the USA, it's people in, like... Sudan, where a civil war is killing hundreds of thousands, and the global media generally just does not care one bit.

So I think if you take away the only leverage that humans naturally have - the ability to be useful to others through work - then the leverage that many people have to secure fair treatment for themselves and their communities will drop to literally zero.

Previous waves of automation did not have this problem, because there's always some other thing you can switch to working on. This time, no. And the square kilometers of land that all the people live on and get food from will be wanted by ASIs to build data centers and generate electricity.

Sure, maybe you only need 1% of wealth to be held by people/govts that are nice, who will outbid them. But it's a huge gamble that things will turn out well.

Indeed, but I think ethics (in a broad sense) is the domain where the selection pressure to make really powerful galaxy brain arguments is the strongest.

decryption has neither of these properties

For voting, ZK does not offer coercion resistance, you do need {trusted party | MPC | FHE | TEE} for that.

But what you *can* do is layer ZK and eg. FHE together, so that even if the FHE breaks, you still have every property except coercion resistance due to the ZK.

I suspect a similar thing applies for almost every other usecase of crypto-other-than-ZK (you should stack it with ZK so that you get ZK-level guarantees for as many apps / as much data as possible)

the point of the ZK is not solely integrity, it's to anonymize the voter identity client-side.

The coercion-resistance gadget (allowing duplicate votes and only counting the first or last) happens inside fhe or tee, but that already operates over nullifiers, not raw identities

also:

* Kohaku roadmap (wallet-side privacy work, including work on often-less-mentioned areas like reading the state privately with TEE+ORAM and later PIR)
* BAL + ZK-EVM provers (along with other benefits, makes a full node much lighter, letting you query state without giving data to an RPC node)
* 7701 (along with other benefits, full AA means there's in-protocol support for privacy protocols without specialized public broadcaster intermediaries)
* keccak -> [likely poseidon] binary tree (along with other benefits, makes it much easier to prove state client-side, enabling better integration between ethereum and privacy apps, eg. zkPOAP)
* ZK-EVM prover improvements + future VM change (along with other benefits, enables "private account abstraction" which lets you have the same account control your public and private funds, change keys for all your private state with one tx, and many other benefits)
* proof aggregation protocols (makes privacy-preserving ops not cost 300k gas each)

Making ethereum L1 fully privacy-friendly is a deep project!

The system is having a tough time today, with TPS much higher than usual.  What this means:
- UI/UX is slower.  The actual sequencer is still as low latency as ever, but the API layer in between that and the front end is slow (web2 type issue).
- it's taking longer to generate proofs on Ethereum, so withdrawals are slowed down as a result.  

Temporary solutions:
- We are adding more liquidity to the Arbitrum fast withdrawal bridge
- We have rate limited the API traders (HFTs and MMs) a bit until things go back to normal.

Why is BTC moving up so slowly this cycle?

BTC supply is concentrated around OG whales who peaked their holdings in 2011 (orange and dark orange).

They bought their BTC at $10 or lower. It takes $110k+ of new capital to absorb each BTC they sell.

This differential in cost basis, the supply they hold and their rate of selling has profound impacts on how much new capital that needs to come in to lift price.

You can look at this as BTC going through growing pains until these 10,000x gain investors are absorbed.

Agree on diminishing returns, but the point I'm making is it's NOT mature. 

A mature asset like gold (6000 yrs of use) doesn't have early holders selling who gained 10,000x.

To understand this chart we first need to break down what a long term hold is defined by it means a coin that has moved to a new address 5 months ago or more. 

So an increase in LTH supply means 5 months ago there was an influx of capital into the network and those newly bought coins have now aged 5 months.

Thats to say an uplift in LTH supply is not real time but actually 5 months laggy.

Any decrease in LTH supply is an immediate sell out of that aged supply. 

There_ always a background noise of people who bought more than 5 months ago selling (not OGs). If it_ steep then that_ a solid profit taking event. 

TLDR; there_ only a few localised drops of local profit taking of tops here.

The rest a misleadingly bearish looking chart. That_ an inherent problem with using LTH and STH metrics but they do serve a use case when bringing the data into models.
Most of the classical onchain metrics will be drifting due to coins interacting invisibly inside ETFs and Treasury Conpanies with ownership being traded without an onchain signature.

A coin bought 1 day ago has more chance of selling than one bought 10 years ago. 

At 5 months of hodl, it turns out the chances of selling starts a phase change to being much less likely. Hence the label LT supply.

DUMMIES GUIDE TO BEING QUANTUM SAFE.

In the past it was about protecting your PRIVATE KEY (your seed phrase). In the age of big scary quantum computers (BSQC) that are coming, you need to protect your PUBLIC KEY also.

Basically a BSQC can figure out your private key from a public key.

The present day taproot addresses (the latest format) are NOT safe, these are addresses starting with "bc1p" and they embed the public key into the address, not good.

Prior formats hide the public key behind a hash, so a BSQC can't easily crack it.

Do this:

1) create a new segwit wallet. It will start with "bc1q" (NOT "bc1p"), you can use older formats too like ones starting with "1" and "3"

2) send all your BTC into this new address

3) you can continue to stack sats into this new address

4) NEVER send BTC out of it, once you do you're BSQC hackable because your public key is revealed

5) wait for Bitcoin to upgrade to a quantum safe protocol, this may take 7 years, who knows

6) send your BTC into the new quantum safe address when the network is NOT congested, once you send, you reveal the private key for a short time. It's unlikely a BSQC will steal your coins in that short window

It's a intermediary measure.

Some ramifications:

All the BTC sitting in ETFs, Treasury companies, and exchange cold storage can be quantum resistant if the custodians take action, even before BTC soft forks into a quantum resistant protocol.

Wallet Apps can also take appropriate action (making sure any spend from an address also moves remaining coins to a new non-taproot address).

Satoshi's 1M coins using an ancient P2PK address will be stolen (unless a future softfork freezes them). So are lost coins in addresses where there's past spending activity.

If it's to an non-taproot address that has never had any of those coins leave, you're good.

Once any BTC leaves an address, you've left a heat signature for a BSQC to hack, you need to move all of them to a new (non-taproot) address for safety.

The new average investor is going to buy through an ETF and it'll be done for them.

If the network is massively congested (say in the case there's a rush to move all non-lost BTC to new quantum safe addresses, which some estimate as needing 1 year complete at max throughput) then a tx can stay in the mempool for a long time and a short range attack becomes a long range attack due to the time available to crack the private key.

Come Q-Day it'll be long range attacks, it would take another 5-10 years of advances in quantum compute before short range attacks become realistic (cracking the private key "in seconds" from a tx sitting in a mempool)

Markets don_ follow the expansion of Global M2, they are speculative. This means they price in the liquidity of expectation ahead of time. Risk assets lead M2.

Hence at global tops you_l see SPX top out early, but you also see BTC top out earlier. This is because BTC acts like a liquidity sensing mechanism. 

Furthermore M2 is a flawed metric because when you assess the amount of fiat money in the system, you_e measuring it in USD but only 17% of it is actual dollars, the rest is in foreign currencies (China has double the USD supply sitting in Yuan equivalent). So M2 is really is a statement on USD strength or weakness. 

As it turns out there_ a metric for this called DXY and this is a much better metric to use when assessing correlation to BTC.

BTC vs inverse trend in US Dollar Index (DXY).

DXY is considered an indicator of risk sentiment by investors.

High DXY (strong dollar) means a flight towards safety and risk off sentiments by investors. Underlying this statement is the reality (for now) that USD is considered a safe haven currency (nevermind in long time frames it debases at 7% per year).

The fastest way for Bitcoin's infrastructure to prepare for post-quantum is for BTC wallets to move to HD wallets with transaction policy tweaks.

This can be implemented quickly without a protocol update and is very cheap on blockchain space.

Explainer:

5-10 yrs is the expected timeline for long range attacks to be viable ("Q-Day"). Moving to HD wallets with transaction policy tweaks will be resistant to Q-Day.

Short range attacks come another 4-8 years later, that's when HD wallets become vulnerable.

So with very little effort and cost, it buys 9-18 yrs of time  to do a post-quantum upgrade to the protocol.

(Satoshi's coins and addresses with reuse will still be vulnerable, but whether to burn those coins is a different discussion)

x.com/woonomic/status/198805

Extra explainer:

An HD wallet is a wallet that controls many derived addresses with a single seed phrase.

Whenever you send BTC, you publish the public key onto the blockchain so that address is now quantum vulnerable (quantum computers can crack a private key from a public key).

So whenever you send BTC, a good HD wallet should move the remaining coins to a new address inside the series of HD addresses controlled by the wallet, hence the public key holding the coins are never revealed.

HD wallets have been around for a while, the update they need is to do the last step. Also to never publish your xpub (a way to derive all of your public keys in an HD wallet).

An on-chain vault is NOT equivalent to a traditional fund just like an on-chain borrow lend is NOT equivalent to a traditional bank.

This is an extremely lossy analogy. 

There's a slight overlap in that they both pool capital in search of yield, but that's where the analogy stops.

The accountability, disclosures, legal recourse, consumer protections that make it safe for your inlaws to put their life savings in traditional funds are absolutely lacking on permissionless DeFi atm.

That's why comparisons of Morpho with traditional funds or Aave with traditional banks are apples to oranges and dangerously misleading.

That doesn't mean there isn't alpha and a risk premium to be earned by those skilled to navigate these systems, we just have to be honest tho.

Eventually it's gonna happen. 

Just a matter if time.
